revision.text:
[[Image:Ahmed moosa.jpg|thumb|150px|Ahmed Moosa, [[November 2003]]]] '''Ahmed S. I. Moosa''' ([[November 4]], [[1968]]), commonly known as '''Ahmed Moosa''' or ''sappé'', is a member [[Maldivian Democratic Party]]'s general council. He is a widely outspoken critic of the current Maldivian government and the president [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]]. Mr. Moosa is currently living in exile in [[United Kingdom]] with his wife and 5 children.
==Early life== {{section-stub}} Moosa was born in [[Maldives]]. Before his political career began, Moosa filled serveral goverment posts and was a successfull businessman.
==Educational background== In [[1990]] Moosa aquired General Certificate of Education grade A [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On [[July 13]], [[1995]] he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with Bachelor of Engineering with Honours in Mechanical Engineering. Two years later, in [[1997]], he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] aquring Master of Philosophy (Engineering) in Metallurgy and Materials.
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/ Political website of Mr. Moosa] ''banned in Maldives''

[[Image:Ahmed moosa.jpg|thumb|150px|Ahmed Moosa, [[November 2003]]]] '''Ahmed S. I. Moosa''' (އަހުމަދް މޫސާ) ([[November 4]], [[1968]]), commonly known as '''Ahmed Moosa''' or ''sappé'', is a member of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]]'s general council. He is a widely outspoken critic of the current Maldivian government and the president [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]]. Mr. Moosa is currently living in exile in [[United Kingdom]] with his wife and 5 children.
==Early and personal life== Moosa was born in [[Malé]], [[Maldives]]. He married to Miranda Moosa in [[1993]], with whome he had three sons; Adam, Micheal and Daniel. In [[2002]] they had an amicable [[divorce]]. Later that year he married Fathimath Moosa, with whome he had son Alexander and daughter Enya Angel.
Before his political career began, Moosa filled serveral government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Private Limited. This company was mainly involved in consultancy work in engineering, web design, printing & publishing, composition of business and marketing proposals and reports and many more.
==Educational background== Moosa completed his secondary education at [[Male' English School]], [[Malé]]. In [[1990]] he aquired General Certificate of Education grade A, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On [[July 13]], [[1995]] he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with Bachelor of Engineering with Honours in Mechanical Engineering. Two years later, in [[1997]], he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] aquring Master of Philosophy (Engineering) in Metallurgy and Materials.
==Political carrer== [[Image:Sappeonbbc.jpg|thumb|200px|Ahmed MoosaSappé on [[BBC]] World Asia Today program, [[June 10]], [[2004]]]] In [[september 19]], [[2003]], [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severly beatun up and ultimately paid with his life; end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a civil unrest in the capital city of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. International media, namely [[BBC]], covered this unusual event. Moosa gave an interview to BBC on the following month and left Maldives, on [[October 15]], [[2003]], to [[United Kingdom]] where he completed his [[Masters]]. The interview, however, was aired on [[October 17]], [[2003]]. He claims that he left the country because he believe he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on [[November 10]], [[2003]], soon after it's official announcement and currently is a member of it's general council. However, he does not get involved with day to day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview to [[BBC]] ([[October 2003]]), he gave several other interviews on different occasions. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian govermnet and was usually responded.
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/ Political website of Mr. Moosa] ''banned in Maldives''
[[Category:1968 births|Moosa, Ahmed]] [[Category:Maldives]]

[[Image:Ahmed moosa.jpg|thumb|150px|Ahmed Moosa, [[November 2003]]]] '''Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa''' (އަހްމަދު ޝަފީގް އިބްރާހިމް މޫސާ) ([[November 4]], [[1968]]), commonly known as '''Ahmed Moosa''' or ''sappé''. He is a widely outspoken critic of the current Maldivian government and the president [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]]. Mr. Moosa is currently living in exile in [[United Kingdom]] with his wife and 5 children.
==Early and personal life== Moosa was born in [[Malé]], [[Maldives]]. He married to Miranda Moosa in [[1993]], with whom he had three sons; Adam, Micheal and Daniel. In [[2002]] they had an amicable [[divorce]]. Later that year he married Fathimath Moosa, with whom he had son Alexander and daughter Enya Angel.
Before his political career began, Moosa filled several government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Private Limited. This company was mainly involved in consultancy work in engineering, web design, printing & publishing, composition of business and marketing proposals and reports and many more.
==Educational background== Moosa completed his secondary education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. In [[1990]] he acquired General Certificate of Education grade A, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On [[July 13]], [[1995]] he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with Bachelor of Engineering with Honours in Mechanical Engineering. Two years later, in [[1997]], he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring Master of Philosophy (Engineering) in Metallurgy and Materials.
==Political carrer== [[Image:Sappeonbbc.jpg|thumb|200px|Ahmed Moosa on [[BBC]] World Asia Today program, [[June 10]], [[2004]]]] In [[september 19]], [[2003]], [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life; end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a civil unrest in the capital city of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. International media, namely [[BBC]], covered this unusual event. Moosa gave an interview to BBC on the following month and left Maldives, on [[October 15]], [[2003]], to [[United Kingdom]]. The interview, however, was aired on [[October 17]], [[2003]]. He claims that he left the country because he believes he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on [[November 10]], [[2003]], soon after it's official announcement and currently is a member of it's general council. However, he does not get involved with day to day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview to [[BBC]] ([[October 2003]]), he gave several other interviews on different occasions. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government and were usually responded.
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/ Political website of Mr. Moosa] ''banned in Maldives''
[[Category:1968 births|Moosa, Ahmed]] [[Category:Maldivian political figures]] [[Category:Maldives]]

[[Image:Ahmed moosa 2005.png|thumb|126px|Ahmed Moosa]] '''Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa''' (އަހްމަދު ޝަފީގް އިބްރާހިމް މޫސާ) ([[November 4]], [[1968]]), commonly known as '''Ahmed Moosa''' or ''sappé'', is a member of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]]'s general council. He is a widely outspoken critic of the current Maldivian government and the president [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]]. Mr. Moosa is currently living in self proclaimed exile in [[United Kingdom]] with his wife and 5 children. He has major financial links with Sri Lankan and Maldivian business associates based in Colombo who collectively fund his personal website (see below) as well as the organisation of the another small group of self proclaimed dissidents known as the MDP (Maldevian Democratic Party). There are also political and financial associations with political groups such as Friends of Maldives and Minivan News.
==Early and personal life== Moosa was born in [[Malé]], [[Maldives]]. He married to Miranda Moosa in [[1993]], with whom he had three sons. In [[2002]] they had an difficult [[divorce]]. Later that year he married Fathimath Moosa, with whom he had a son and a daughter. He is known to be a serial womaniser.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on [[November 10]], [[2003]], soon after it's official announcement and currently is a member of it's general council.
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/ Political website of Mr. Moosa] ''banned in Maldives''

On [[July 13]], [[1995]] he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with Bachelor of Engineering with Honours in Mechanical Engineering. Two years later, in [[1997]], he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring Master of Philosophy (Engineering) in Metallurgy and Materials.
==Political carrer== [[Image:Sappeonbbc.jpg|thumb|200px|Ahmed Moosa on [[BBC]] World Asia Today program, [[June 10]], [[2004]]]] In [[september 19]], [[2003]], [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life; end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a civil unrest in the capital city of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. International media, namely [[BBC]], covered this unusual event. Moosa gave an interview to BBC on the following month and left Maldives, on [[October 15]], [[2003]], to [[United Kingdom]]. The interview, however, was aired on [[October 17]], [[2003]]. He claims that he left the country because he believes he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on [[November 10]], [[2003]], soon after it's official announcement and currently is a member of it's general council. However, he does not get involved with day to day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview to [[BBC]] ([[October 2003]]), he gave several other interviews on different occasions. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government and were usually responded.
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/ Political website of Mr. Moosa] ''banned in Maldives''

==Educational background== Moosa completed his primary education gd.thinadhoo school and shouting for he is a president of maldives. now in three times he send to maldivian jail also. ==Political carrer== [[Image:Sappeonbbc.jpg|thumb|200px|Ahmed Moosa on [[BBC]] World Asia Today program, [[June 10]], [[2004]]]] In [[september 19]], [[2003]], [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life; end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a civil unrest in the capital city of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. International media, namely [[BBC]], covered this unusual event. Moosa gave an interview to BBC on the following month and left Maldives, on [[October 15]], [[2003]], to [[United Kingdom]]. The interview, however, was aired on [[October 17]], [[2003]]. He claims that he left the country because he believes he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on [[November 10]], [[2003]], soon after it's official announcement and currently is a member of it's general council. However, he does not get involved with day to day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview to [[BBC]] ([[October 2003]]), he gave several other interviews on different occasions. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government and were usually responded.

Before his political career began, Moosa filled several government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Private Limited. International media, namely [[BBC]], covered this unusual event. Moosa gave an interview to BBC on the following month and left Maldives, on [[October 15]], [[2003]], to [[United Kingdom]]. The interview, however, was aired on [[October 17]], [[2003]]. He claims that he left the country because he believes he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on [[November 10]], [[2003]], soon after its official announcement and currently is a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day to day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview to [[BBC]] ([[October 2003]]), he gave several other interviews on different occasions. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government and were usually responded.
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/ Political website of Mr. Moosa] ''banned in Maldives'' **[http://www.dhivehiobserver.org/ Mirror]

revision.text:
[[Image:Ahmed moosa 2005.png|thumb|126px|Ahmed Moosa]] '''Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa''' ([[Dhivehi]]: އަހްމަދު ޝަފީގް އިބްރާހިމް މޫސާ) ('''b.''' [[November 4]], [[1968]]), commonly known as '''Ahmed Moosa''' or ''sappé'', is a member of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]]'s general council. He is a widely outspoken critic of the current Maldivian [[government]] and the president [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]]. Moosa is currently living in self-proclaimed [[exile]] in the [[United Kingdom]] with his family.
==Early and personal life== Moosa was born in [[Malé]], [[Maldives]]. He married to Miranda Moosa in [[1993]], with whom he had three sons. In [[2002]] they had an amicable [[divorce]]. Later that year he married Fathimath Moosa, with whom he had a son and a daughter.
Before his political career began, Moosa filled several government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Private Limited. This company was mainly involved in consultancy work in engineering, web design, printing & publishing, composition of business and marketing proposals and reports and many more.
==Educational background== Moosa completed his secondary education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. In [[1990]] he acquired General Certificate of Education grade A, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On [[July 13]], [[1995]] he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with Bachelor of Engineering with Honours in Mechanical Engineering. Two years later, in [[1997]], he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring Master of Philosophy (Engineering) in Metallurgy and Materials.
==Political career== [[Image:Sappeonbbc.jpg|thumb|200px|Ahmed Moosa on [[BBC]] World Asia Today program, [[June 10]], [[2004]]]] In [[september 19]], [[2003]], [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life; end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. International media, namely [[BBC]], covered this unusual event. Moosa gave an interview to BBC on the following month and left Maldives, on [[October 15]], [[2003]], to [[United Kingdom]]. The interview, however, was aired on [[October 17]], [[2003]]. He claims that he left the country because he believes he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on [[November 10]], [[2003]], soon after its official announcement and currently is a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day to day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview to [[BBC]] ([[October 2003]]), he gave several other interviews on different occasions. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government and were usually responded.
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.org/ Dhivehiobserver, a satirically political website of Moosa] [[Category:1968 births|Moosa, Ahmed]] [[Category:Maldivian politicians|Moosa, Ahmed]] [[Category:Democracy activists|Moosa, Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim]]

Before his political career began, Moosa filled several unsuccessful government and private company posts. He also tried to manage and run his own businesses, but failed. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Private Limited. This company was mainly involved in consultancy work in engineering, web design, printing & publishing, composition of business and marketing proposals and reports and many more.
==Educational background== Moosa completed his secondarys education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. In [[1990]] he acquired General Certificate of Education grade A, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On [[July 13]], [[1995]] he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with Bachelor of Engineering with Honours in Mechanical Engineering. Two years later, in [[1997]], he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring Master of Philosophy (Engineering) in Metallurgy and Materials.
==Political career== [[Image:Sappeonbbc.jpg|thumb|200px|Ahmed Moosa on [[BBC]] World Asia Today program, [[June 10]], [[2004]]]] In [[september 19]], [[2003]], [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life; end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. International media, namely [[BBC]], covered this unusual event. Moosa gave an interview to BBC on the following month and left Maldives, on [[October 15]], [[2003]], to [[United Kingdom]]. The interview, however, was aired on [[October 17]], [[2003]]. He claims that he left the country because he believes he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on [[November 10]], [[2003]], soon after its official announcement and currently is a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day to day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview to [[BBC]] ([[October 2003]]), he gave several other interviews on different occasions. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government and were usually responded.

International media, namely [[BBC]], covered this unusual event. Moosa gave an interview to BBC on the following month and left Maldives, on [[October 15]], [[2003]], to [[United Kingdom]]. The interview, however, was aired on [[October 17]], [[2003]]. He claims that he left the country because he believes he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said sappé in a written statement published on his website.

<!-- Unsourced image removed: [[Image:Ahmed moosa 2005.png|thumb|126px|Ahmed Moosa]] --> '''Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa''' ([[Dhivehi]]: އަހްމަދު ޝަފީގް އިބްރާހިމް މޫސާ) ('''b.''' [[November 4]], [[1968]]), commonly known as '''Ahmed Moosa''' or ''sappé'', is a member of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]]'s general council. He is a widely outspoken critic of the current Maldivian [[government]] and the president [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]]. Moosa is currently living in self-proclaimed [[exile]] in the [[United Kingdom]] with his family.
==Early and personal life== Moosa was born in [[Malé]], [[Maldives]]. He married to Miranda Moosa in [[1993]], with whom he had three sons. In [[2002]] they had a [[divorce]] due to Moosa's domestic violence. Later that year he married Fathimath Moosa, with whom he had a son and a daughter.
Before his political career began, Moosa filled several government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Private Limited. This company was mainly involved in consultancy work in engineering, web design, printing & publishing, composition of business and marketing proposals and reports and many more.
Moosa is a failed businessman who is sought after by many creditors over unsettled debts.
==Educational background== Moosa completed his secondarys education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. In [[1990]] he acquired General Certificate of Education grade A, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On [[July 13]], [[1995]] he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with Bachelor of Engineering with Honours in Mechanical Engineering. Two years later, in [[1997]], he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring Master of Philosophy (Engineering) in Metallurgy and Materials. He was refused the opportunity to carry on for a doctorate by [[University of Birmingham]].
==Political career== [[Image:Sappeonbbc.jpg|thumb|200px|Ahmed Moosa on [[BBC]] World Asia Today program, [[June 10]], [[2004]]]] In [[september 19]], [[2003]], [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life; end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. The offending wardens were tried and sentenced in Maldivian courts. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. International media, namely [[BBC]], covered this unusual event. Moosa gave an interview to BBC on the following month and left Maldives, on [[October 15]], [[2003]], to [[United Kingdom]]. The interview, however, was aired on [[October 17]], [[2003]]. He claims that he left the country because he believes he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said sappé in a written statement published on his website.
Although Moosa claims this to be the case, it is widely believed that he left the country to avoid his creditors. It is believed that he owes over 55,000 Dollars.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on [[November 10]], [[2003]], soon after its official announcement and currently is a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day to day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview to [[BBC]] ([[October 2003]]), he gave several other interviews on different occasions. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government and were usually responded.
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.org/ Dhivehiobserver, a petty website based on heresay operated by the unemployed Moosa
[[Category:1968 births|Moosa, Ahmed]] [[Category:Living people|Moosa, Ahmed]] [[Category:Maldivian politicians|Moosa, Ahmed]] [[Category:Democracy activists|Moosa, Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim]]

[[Image:Sappeonbbc.jpg|thumb|200px|Ahmed Moosa on [[BBC]] World Asia Today program, [[June 10]], [[2004]]]] '''Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa''' ([[Dhivehi]]: އަހްމަދު ޝަފީގް އިބްރާހިމް މޫސާ) ('''b.''' [[November 4]], [[1968]]), commonly known as '''Ahmed Moosa''' or ''sappé'', is a member of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]]'s general council. He is a widely outspoken critic of the current Maldivian [[government]] and the president [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]]. Moosa is currently living in self-proclaimed [[exile]] in the [[United Kingdom]] with his family.
==Educational background== Moosa completed his secondarys education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. In [[1990]] he acquired General Certificate of Education grade A, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On [[July 13]], [[1995]] he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with Bachelor of Engineering with Honours in Mechanical Engineering. Two years later, in [[1997]], he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring Master of Philosophy (Engineering) in Metallurgy and Materials.
==Political career== In [[september 19]], [[2003]], [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life; end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. International media, namely [[BBC]], covered this unusual event. Moosa gave an interview to BBC on the following month and left Maldives, on [[October 15]], [[2003]], to [[United Kingdom]]. The interview, however, was aired on [[October 17]], [[2003]]. He claims that he left the country because he believes he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on [[November 10]], [[2003]], soon after its official announcement and currently is a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day to day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview to [[BBC]] ([[October 2003]]), he gave several other interviews on different occasions. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government and were usually responded.
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.org/ Dhivehiobserver, a satirically political website by Moosa] - ''banned in the [[Maldives]]''
[[Category:1968 births|Moosa, Ahmed]] [[Category:Living people|Moosa, Ahmed]] [[Category:Maldivian politicians|Moosa, Ahmed]] [[Category:Democracy activists|Moosa, Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim]]

[[Image:Sappeonbbc.jpg|thumb|200px|Ahmed Moosa on [[BBC]] World Asia Today program, [[June 10]], [[2004]]]] '''Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa''' ([[Dhivehi]]: އަހްމަދު ޝަފީގް އިބްރާހިމް މޫސާ) ('''b.''' He is a widely outspoken critic of the current Maldivian [[government]] and the president [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]]. Moosa is currently living in self-proclaimed [[exile]] in the [[United Kingdom]] with his family.
==Early and personal life== Moosa was born in [[Malé]], [[Maldives]]. He married to Miranda Moosa in [[1993]], with whom he had three sons. In [[2002]] they had a [[divorce]]. Later that year he married Fathimath Moosa, with whom he had a son and a daughter.
Before his political career began, Moosa filled several government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Private Limited. This company was mainly involved in consultancy work in engineering, web design, printing & publishing, composition of business and marketing proposals and reports and many more.
==Educational background== Moosa completed his secondarys education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. In [[1990]] he acquired General Certificate of Education grade A, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On [[July 13]], [[1995]] he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with Bachelor of Engineering with Honours in Mechanical Engineering. Two years later, in [[1997]], he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring Master of Philosophy (Engineering) in Metallurgy and Materials.

On [[July 13]], [[1995]] he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with Bachelor of Engineering with Honours in Mechanical Engineering. Two years later, in [[1997]], he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring Master of Philosophy (Engineering) in Metallurgy and Materials.
==Political career== In [[september 19]], [[2003]], [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life; end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. International media, namely [[BBC]], covered this unusual event. Moosa gave an interview to BBC on the following month and left Maldives, on [[October 15]], [[2003]], to [[United Kingdom]]. The interview, however, was aired on [[October 17]], [[2003]]. He claims that he left the country because he believes he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on [[November 10]], [[2003]], soon after its official announcement and currently is a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day to day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview to [[BBC]] ([[October 2003]]), he gave several other interviews on different occasions. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government and were usually responded.
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.org/ Dhivehiobserver, a satirically political website by Moosa] - ''banned in the [[Maldives]]''

Before his political career began, Moosa filled several government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Private Limited. International media, namely [[BBC]], covered this unusual event. Moosa gave an interview to BBC on the following month and left Maldives, on [[October 15]], [[2003]], to [[United Kingdom]]. The interview, however, was aired on [[October 17]], [[2003]]. He claims that he left the country because he believes he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on [[November 10]], [[2003]], soon after its official announcement and currently is a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day to day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview to [[BBC]] ([[October 2003]]), he gave several other interviews on different occasions. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government and were usually responded.
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.org/ Dhivehiobserver, a satirically political website by Moosa] - ''banned in the [[Maldives]]''

[[Image:Sappeonbbc.jpg|thumb|200px|Ahmed Moosa on [[BBC]] World Asia Today program, [[June 10]], [[2004]]]] '''Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa''' ([[Dhivehi]]: އަހްމަދު ޝަފީގް އިބްރާހިމް މޫސާ) ('''b.''' [[November 4]], [[1968]]), commonly known as '''Ahmed Moosa''' or ''sappé'', is a member of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]]'s general council. He is a widely outspoken critic of the current Maldivian [[government]] and the president [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]]. Moosa is currently living in self-proclaimed [[exile]] in the [[United Kingdom]] with his family.
==Early and personal life== Moosa was born in [[Malé]], [[Maldives]]. He married to Miranda Moosa in [[1993]], with whom he had three sons. In [[2002]] they had a [[divorce]]. Later that year he married Fathimath Moosa, with whom he had a son and a daughter.
Before his political career began, Moosa filled several government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Private Limited. This company was mainly involved in consultancy work in engineering, web design, printing & publishing, composition of business and marketing proposals and reports and many more.
==Educational background== Moosa completed his secondarys education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. In [[1990]] he acquired General Certificate of Education grade A, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On [[July 13]], [[1995]] he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with Bachelor of Engineering with Honours in Mechanical Engineering. Two years later, in [[1997]], he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring Master of Philosophy (Engineering) in Metallurgy and Materials.
==Political career== In [[september 19]], [[2003]], [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life; end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. International media, namely [[BBC]], covered this unusual event. Moosa gave an interview to BBC on the following month and left Maldives, on [[October 15]], [[2003]], to [[United Kingdom]]. The interview, however, was aired on [[October 17]], [[2003]]. He claims that he left the country because he believes he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on [[November 10]], [[2003]], soon after its official announcement and currently is a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day to day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview to [[BBC]] ([[October 2003]]), he gave several other interviews on different occasions. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government and were usually responded.

The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act. [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/15/wmald15.xml] [http://www.minivannews.com/news/news.php?id=2420]

revision.comment: /* Early and personal life */about ilyas ibrahim
revision.text:
[[Image:Sappeonbbc.jpg|thumb|200px|Ahmed Moosa on [[BBC]] World Asia Today program, [[June 10]], [[2004]]]] '''Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa''' ([[Dhivehi]]: އަހްމަދު ޝަފީގް އިބްރާހިމް މޫސާ) ('''b.''' [[November 4]], [[1968]]), commonly known as '''Ahmed Moosa''' or ''sappé'', is a member of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]]'s general council. He is a widely outspoken critic of the current Maldivian [[government]] and the president [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]]. Moosa is currently living in self-proclaimed [[exile]] in the [[United Kingdom]] with his family.
==Early and personal life== Moosa was born in [[Malé]], [[Maldives]]. He married to Miranda Moosa in [[1993]], with whom he had three sons. In [[2002]] they had a [[divorce]]. Later that year he married Fathimath Moosa, with whom he had a son and a daughter.
Before his political career began, Moosa filled several government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Private Limited. This company was mainly involved in consultancy work in engineering, web design, printing & publishing, composition of business and marketing proposals and reports and many more.
Moosa was practically involved in designing and production of the election campaign material for [[Ilyas Ibrahim]] (brother-in-law of the president Gayyoom) in 1999 who ran against [[Mohamed Nasheed]] (of the opposition) for representing the people of Malé as a member of the parliment. "I worked in Ilyas's last campaign (1999) on the request of Mr. Qasim Ibrahim which later turned out to be a regrettable experience." [http://www.minvanradio.com/do/maldives_statement_21Nov2004_dhivehiobserver.htm]
==Educational background== Moosa completed his secondarys education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. In [[1990]] he acquired General Certificate of Education grade A, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On [[July 13]], [[1995]] he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with Bachelor of Engineering with Honours in Mechanical Engineering. Two years later, in [[1997]], he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring Master of Philosophy (Engineering) in Metallurgy and Materials.
==Political career== In [[september 19]], [[2003]], [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life; end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. International media, namely [[BBC]], covered this unusual event. Moosa gave an interview to BBC on the following month and left Maldives, on [[October 15]], [[2003]], to [[United Kingdom]]. The interview, however, was aired on [[October 17]], [[2003]]. He claims that he left the country because he believes he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on [[November 10]], [[2003]], soon after its official announcement and currently is a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day to day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview to [[BBC]] ([[October 2003]]), he gave several other interviews on different occasions. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government and were usually responded.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on [[September 15]], [[2006]], Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on [[April 11]], [[2005]]. Mr. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in [[London]]. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act. [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/15/wmald15.xml] [http://www.minivannews.com/news/news.php?id=2420]
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.org/ Dhivehiobserver, a satirically political website by Moosa] - ''banned in the [[Maldives]]''

[[Image:Sappeonbbc.jpg|thumb|200px|Ahmed Moosa on [[BBC]] World Asia Today program, [[June 10]], [[2004]]]] '''Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa''' ([[Dhivehi]]: އަހްމަދު ޝަފީގް އިބްރާހިމް މޫސާ) ('''b.''' [[November 4]], [[1968]]), commonly known as '''Ahmed Moosa''' or ''sappé'', is a member of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]]'s general council. He is a widely outspoken critic of the current Maldivian [[government]] and the president [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]]. Moosa is currently living in self-proclaimed [[exile]] in the [[United Kingdom]] with his family.
==Early and personal life== Moosa was born in [[Malé]], [[Maldives]]. He married to Miranda Moosa in [[1993]], with whom he had three sons. In [[2002]] they had a [[divorce]]. Later that year he married Fathimath Moosa, with whom he had a son and a daughter.
Before his political career began, Moosa filled several government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Private Limited. This company was mainly involved in consultancy work in engineering, web design, printing & publishing, composition of business and marketing proposals and reports and many more.
Moosa was practically involved in designing and production of the election campaign material for [[Ilyas Ibrahim]] (brother-in-law of the president Gayyoom) in 1999 who ran against [[Mohamed Nasheed]] (of the opposition) for representing the people of Malé as a member of the parliament. "I worked in Ilyas's last campaign (1999) on the request of Mr. Qasim Ibrahim which later turned out to be a regrettable experience." [http://www.minvanradio.com/do/maldives_statement_21Nov2004_dhivehiobserver.htm]
Since 1999 Moosa has been a consultant to [[Qasim Ibrahim]], current finance minister and [[Maldivian Peoples Party|DRP's]] (ruling party) deputy leader.[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa/CV%20of%20ASIMoosa.htm] Moosa is currently a director of [http://www.horizonfisheries.com/ Horizon Fisheries Private Limited], a company with majority shares owned by Qasim Ibraim and former DRP member of parliament, Ahmed Nashid (ADK).
==Educational background== Moosa completed his secondarys education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. In [[1990]] he acquired General Certificate of Education grade A, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On [[July 13]], [[1995]] he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with Bachelor of Engineering with Honours in Mechanical Engineering. Two years later, in [[1997]], he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring Master of Philosophy (Engineering) in Metallurgy and Materials.
==Political career== In [[september 19]], [[2003]], [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life; end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. International media, namely [[BBC]], covered this unusual event. Moosa gave an interview to BBC on the following month and left Maldives, on [[October 15]], [[2003]], to [[United Kingdom]]. The interview, however, was aired on [[October 17]], [[2003]]. He claims that he left the country because he believes he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on [[November 10]], [[2003]], soon after its official announcement and currently is a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day to day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview to [[BBC]] ([[October 2003]]), he gave several other interviews on different occasions. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government and were usually responded.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on [[September 15]], [[2006]], Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on [[April 11]], [[2005]]. Mr. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in [[London]]. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act. [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/15/wmald15.xml] [http://www.minivannews.com/news/news.php?id=2420]

"I have already left the country fearing the worst" said sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on [[November 10]], [[2003]], soon after its official announcement and currently is a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day to day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview to [[BBC]] ([[October 2003]]), he gave several other interviews on different occasions. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government and were usually responded.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on [[September 15]], [[2006]], Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on [[April 11]], [[2005]]. Mr. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in [[London]]. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act. ==Political career== In [[september 19]], [[2003]], [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life; end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. International media, namely [[BBC]], covered this unusual event. Moosa gave an interview to BBC on the following month and left Maldives, on [[October 15]], [[2003]], to [[United Kingdom]]. The interview, however, was aired on [[October 17]], [[2003]]. He claims that he left the country because he believes he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on [[November 10]], [[2003]], soon after its official announcement and currently is a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day to day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview to [[BBC]] ([[October 2003]]), he gave several other interviews on different occasions. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government and were usually responded.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on [[September 15]], [[2006]], Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on [[April 11]], [[2005]]. Mr. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in [[London]]. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act. [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/15/wmald15.xml] [http://www.minivannews.com/news/news.php?id=2420]

Before his political career began, Moosa filled several government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Private Limited. This company was mainly involved in consultancy work in engineering, web design, printing & publishing, composition of business and marketing proposals and reports and many more.

"I have already left the country fearing the worst" said sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on [[November 10]], [[2003]], soon after its official announcement and currently is a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day to day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview to [[BBC]] (October 2003), he gave several other interviews on different occasions. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government and were usually responded.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on [[September 15]], [[2006]], Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on [[April 11]], [[2005]]. Mr. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in [[London]]. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act. [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/15/wmald15.xml] [http://www.minivannews.com/news/news.php?id=2420]

[[Category:1968 births|Moosa, Ahmed]] [[Category:Living people|Moosa, Ahmed]] [[Category:Maldivian politicians|Moosa, Ahmed]] [[Category:Maldivian Muslims|Moosa, Ahmed]] [[Category:Maldivian democracy activists|Moosa, Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim]]

[[Image:Sappeonbbc.jpg|thumb|200px|Ahmed Moosa on [[BBC]] World Asia Today program, [[June 10]], [[2004]]]] '''Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa''' ([[Dhivehi]]: އަހްމަދު ޝަފީގް އިބްރާހިމް މޫސާ) ('''b.''' [[November 4]], [[1968]]), commonly known as '''Ahmed Moosa''' or ''sappé'', is a member of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]]'s general council. He is a widely outspoken critic of the current Maldivian [[government]] and the president [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]]. Moosa is currently living in self-proclaimed [[exile]] in the [[United Kingdom]] with his family.
==Early and personal life== Moosa was born in [[Malé]], [[Maldives]]. He married to Miranda Moosa in 1993, with whom he had three sons. In 2002 they had a [[divorce]]. Later that year he married Fathimath Moosa, with whom he had a son and a daughter.
Before his political career began, Moosa filled several government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Private Limited. This company was mainly involved in consultancy work in engineering, web design, printing & publishing, composition of business and marketing proposals and reports and many more.
Moosa was practically involved in designing and production of the election campaign material for [[Ilyas Ibrahim]] (brother-in-law of the president Gayyoom) in 1999 who ran against [[Mohamed Nasheed]] (of the opposition) for representing the people of Malé as a member of the parliament. "I worked in Ilyas's last campaign (1999) on the request of Mr. Qasim Ibrahim which later turned out to be a regrettable experience." [http://www.minvanradio.com/do/maldives_statement_21Nov2004_dhivehiobserver.htm]
Since 1999 Moosa has been a consultant to [[Qasim Ibrahim]], current finance minister and [[Maldivian Peoples Party|DRP's]] (ruling party) deputy leader.[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa/CV%20of%20ASIMoosa.htm] Moosa is currently a director of [http://www.horizonfisheries.com/ Horizon Fisheries Private Limited], a company with majority shares owned by Qasim Ibraim and former DRP member of parliament, Ahmed Nashid (ADK).
==Educational background== Moosa completed his secondarys education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. In 1990 he acquired General Certificate of Education grade A, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On [[July 13]], [[1995]] he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with Bachelor of Engineering with Honours in Mechanical Engineering. Two years later, in 1997, he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring Master of Philosophy (Engineering) in Metallurgy and Materials.
==Political career== In [[september 19]], [[2003]], [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life; end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. International media, namely [[BBC]], covered this unusual event. Moosa gave an interview to BBC on the following month and left Maldives, on [[October 15]], [[2003]], to [[United Kingdom]]. The interview, however, was aired on [[October 17]], [[2003]]. He claims that he left the country because he believes he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on [[November 10]], [[2003]], soon after its official announcement and currently is a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day to day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview to [[BBC]] (October 2003), he gave several other interviews on different occasions. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government and were usually responded.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on [[September 15]], [[2006]], Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on [[April 11]], [[2005]]. Mr. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in [[London]]. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act. [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/15/wmald15.xml] [http://www.minivannews.com/news/news.php?id=2420]
==Coming Back to Maldives== In [[November 08]], [[2008]], Mr.Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa or Sappe' has arrived to Male' International Airport. After 5 years in United Kingdom , finally when president Maumoon Abdul Qayyoom has to leave the presidential office , Sappe' or Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa has come to enjoy the new democracy in Maldives and to be there in November 11 , In the day , President Elect Mohamed Nasheed will take the country.
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.org/ Dhivehiobserver, a satirically political website by Moosa] - ''banned in the [[Maldives]]''

Moosa was practically involved in designing and production of the election campaign material for [[Ilyas Ibrahim]] (brother-in-law of the president Gayyoom) in 1999 who ran against [[Mohamed Nasheed]] (of the opposition) for representing the people of Malé as a member of the parliament. "I worked in Ilyas's last campaign (1999) on the request of Mr. Qasim Ibrahim which later turned out to be a regrettable experience." [http://www.minvanradio.com/do/maldives_statement_21Nov2004_dhivehiobserver.htm]
Since 1999 Moosa has been a consultant to [[Qasim Ibrahim]], current finance minister and [[Maldivian Peoples Party|DRP's]] (ruling party) deputy leader.[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa/CV%20of%20ASIMoosa.htm] Moosa is currently a director of [http://www.horizonfisheries.com/ Horizon Fisheries Private Limited], a company with majority shares owned by Qasim Ibraim and former DRP member of parliament, Ahmed Nashid (ADK).
==Educational background== Moosa completed his secondarys education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. In 1990 he acquired General Certificate of Education grade A, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On [[July 13]], [[1995]] he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with Bachelor of Engineering with Honours in Mechanical Engineering. Two years later, in 1997, he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring Master of Philosophy (Engineering) in Metallurgy and Materials.
HOSAM IS A FAGGGGGGOT
==Political career== In [[september 19]], [[2003]], [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life; end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. International media, namely [[BBC]], covered this unusual event. Moosa gave an interview to BBC on the following month and left Maldives, on [[October 15]], [[2003]], to [[United Kingdom]]. The interview, however, was aired on [[October 17]], [[2003]]. He claims that he left the country because he believes he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on [[November 10]], [[2003]], soon after its official announcement and currently is a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day to day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview to [[BBC]] (October 2003), he gave several other interviews on different occasions. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government and were usually responded.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on [[September 15]], [[2006]], Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on [[April 11]], [[2005]]. Mr. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in [[London]]. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act. [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/15/wmald15.xml] [http://www.minivannews.com/news/news.php?id=2420]

[[Image:Sappeonbbc.jpg|thumb|200px|Ahmed Moosa on [[BBC]] World Asia Today program, [[June 10]], [[2004]]]] '''Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa''' ([[Dhivehi]]: އަހްމަދު ޝަފީގް އިބްރާހިމް މޫސާ) ('''b.''' [[November 4]], [[1968]]), commonly known as '''Ahmed Moosa''' or ''sappé'', is a member of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]]'s general council. He is a widely outspoken critic of the current Maldivian [[government]] and the president [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]]. Moosa is currently living in self-proclaimed [[exile]] in the [[United Kingdom]] with his family.
==Early and personal life== Moosa was born in [[Malé]], [[Maldives]]. AHMED MOOSA IS A G [[divorce]]. Later that year he married Fathimath Moosa, with whom he had a son and a daughter.
Before his political career began, Moosa filled several government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Private Limited. This company was mainly involved in consultancy work in engineering, web design, printing & publishing, composition of business and marketing proposals and reports and many more.
Moosa was practically involved in designing and production of the election campaign material for [[Ilyas Ibrahim]] (brother-in-law of the president Gayyoom) in 1999 who ran against [[Mohamed Nasheed]] (of the opposition) for representing the people of Malé as a member of the parliament. "I worked in Ilyas's last campaign (1999) on the request of Mr. Qasim Ibrahim which later turned out to be a regrettable experience." [http://www.minvanradio.com/do/maldives_statement_21Nov2004_dhivehiobserver.htm]
Since 1999 Moosa has been a consultant to [[Qasim Ibrahim]], current finance minister and [[Maldivian Peoples Party|DRP's]] (ruling party) deputy leader.[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa/CV%20of%20ASIMoosa.htm] Moosa is currently a director of [http://www.horizonfisheries.com/ Horizon Fisheries Private Limited], a company with majority shares owned by Qasim Ibraim and former DRP member of parliament, Ahmed Nashid (ADK). I FANCY NIKI BRENNAN.
==Educational background== Moosa completed his secondarys education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. In 1990 he acquired General Certificate of Education grade A, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On [[July 13]], [[1995]] he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with Bachelor of Engineering with Honours in Mechanical Engineering. Two years later, in 1997, he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring Master of Philosophy (Engineering) in Metallurgy and Materials. I AM ADAM MOOSA'S FATHER.
==Political career== In [[september 19]], [[2003]], [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life; end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. International media, namely [[BBC]], covered this unusual event. Moosa gave an interview to BBC on the following month and left Maldives, on [[October 15]], [[2003]], to [[United Kingdom]]. The interview, however, was aired on [[October 17]], [[2003]]. He claims that he left the country because he believes he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on [[November 10]], [[2003]], soon after its official announcement and currently is a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day to day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview to [[BBC]] (October 2003), he gave several other interviews on different occasions. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government and were usually responded.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on [[September 15]], [[2006]], Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on [[April 11]], [[2005]]. Mr. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in [[London]]. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act. [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/15/wmald15.xml] [http://www.minivannews.com/news/news.php?id=2420]

The interview, however, was aired on [[October 17]], [[2003]]. He claims that he left the country because he believes he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on [[November 10]], [[2003]], soon after its official announcement and currently is a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day to day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview to [[BBC]] (October 2003), he gave several other interviews on different occasions. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government and were usually responded.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on [[September 15]], [[2006]], Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on [[April 11]], [[2005]]. Mr. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in [[London]]. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act. [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/15/wmald15.xml] [http://www.minivannews.com/news/news.php?id=2420]

{{pov-check|date=February 2009}} {{unreferenced|date=February 2009}} [[Image:Sappeonbbc.jpg|thumb|200px|Ahmed Moosa on [[BBC]] World Asia Today program, [[June 10]], [[2004]]]] '''Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa''' ([[Dhivehi]]: އަހްމަދު ޝަފީގް އިބްރާހިމް މޫސާ) ('''b.''' [[November 4]], [[1968]]), commonly known as '''Ahmed Moosa''' or ''sappé'', is a founding member of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] and was elected to it's first general council. He is a widely outspoken critic of the current Maldivian [[government]] and the former president [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]]. Moosa lived in self-proclaimed [[exile]] in the [[United Kingdom]] with his family from 2003 - 2008. MDP won the Presidential Election held in October 2008.
Mr. Moosa was appointed Special Envoy for Science and Technology on 11th March 2009. [http://www.presidencymaldives.gov.mv/pages/eng_news.php?news:5388:1]
==Early and personal life== Moosa was born in [[Malé]], [[Maldives]]. He married Miranda Moosa in 1993, with whom he had three sons. The marriage ended in a divorcen in 2002. Later that year he married Fathimath Moosa, with whom he had a son and a daughter.
Before his political career began, Moosa filled several government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Private Limited. This company was mainly involved in consultancy work in engineering, web design, printing & publishing, composition of business and marketing proposals and reports and many more.
Moosa was practically involved in designing and production of the election campaign material for [[Ilyas Ibrahim]] (brother-in-law of the president Gayyoom) in 1999 who ran against [[Mohamed Nasheed]] (of the opposition) for representing the people of Malé as a member of the parliament. "I worked in Ilyas's last campaign (1999) on the request of Mr. Qasim Ibrahim which later turned out to be a regrettable experience." [http://www.minvanradio.com/do/maldives_statement_21Nov2004_dhivehiobserver.htm]
Since 1999 Moosa has been a consultant to [[Qasim Ibrahim]], current finance minister and [[Maldivian Peoples Party|DRP's]] (ruling party) deputy leader.[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa/CV%20of%20ASIMoosa.htm] Moosa is currently a director of [http://www.horizonfisheries.com/ Horizon Fisheries Private Limited], a company with majority shares owned by Qasim Ibraim and former DRP member of parliament, Ahmed Nashid (ADK).
==Educational background== Moosa completed his secondarys education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. In 1990 he acquired General Certificate of Education grade A, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On [[July 13]], [[1995]] he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with Bachelor of Engineering with Honours in Mechanical Engineering. Two years later, in 1997, he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring Master of Philosophy (Engineering) in Metallurgy and Materials.
==Political career== In [[september 19]], [[2003]], [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life; end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. International media, namely [[BBC]], covered this unusual event. Moosa gave an interview to BBC on the following month and left Maldives, on [[October 15]], [[2003]], to [[United Kingdom]]. The interview, however, was aired on [[October 17]], [[2003]]. He claims that he left the country because he believes he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on [[November 10]], [[2003]], soon after its official announcement and currently is a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day to day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview to [[BBC]] (October 2003), he gave several other interviews on different occasions. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government and were usually responded.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on [[September 15]], [[2006]], Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on [[April 11]], [[2005]]. Mr. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in [[London]]. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act. [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/15/wmald15.xml] [http://www.minivannews.com/news/news.php?id=2420]

[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/15/wmald15.xml] [http://www.minivannews.com/news/news.php?id=2420]
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.org/ Dhivehiobserver, a satirically political website by Moosa] - ''was banned in the [[Maldives]] until the government changed in November 2008''
[[Category:1968 births|Moosa, Ahmed]] [[Category:Living people|Moosa, Ahmed]] [[Category:Maldivian politicians|Moosa, Ahmed]] [[Category:Maldivian Muslims|Moosa, Ahmed]] [[Category:Maldivian democracy activists|Moosa, Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim]]

{{pov-check|date=February 2009}} {{unreferenced|date=February 2009}} [[Image:Sappeonbbc.jpg|thumb|200px|Ahmed Moosa on [[BBC]] World Asia Today program, [[June 10]], [[2004]]]] '''Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa''' ([[Dhivehi]]: އަހްމަދު ޝަފީގް އިބްރާހިމް މޫސާ) ('''b.''' [[November 4]], [[1968]]), commonly known as '''Ahmed Moosa''' or ''sappé'', is a senior member of the new democratic government of the [[Maldives]], headed by President [[Mohamed Nasheed]]. He is the Envoy for Science and Technology. He was appointed on 11th March 2009. [http://www.presidencymaldives.gov.mv/pages/eng_news.php?news:5388:1] [http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/maldives-aims-to-become-first-carbonneutral-country-1644907.html]
Mr. Moosa is amongst the important figures who campaigned for democracy and human rights which led to the demise of the regime of Dictator Gayyoom in November 2008. He is the founder and Editor in Chief of the influential news website Dhivehi Observer. [http://www.dhivehiobserver.com][http://www.dhivehi-observer.com/aboutus.html]
Mr. Moosa senior member of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] and was elected to it's first general council. He was a widely outspoken critic of the ousted Maldivian [[government]] and the former president [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]]. Moosa lived in self-proclaimed [[exile]] in the [[United Kingdom]] with his family from 2003 - 2008. MDP won the Presidential Election held in October 2008.
Mr. Moosa is permanently resident in the United Kingdom but makes frequent visits to the Maldives.
==Early and personal life== Moosa was born in [[Malé]], [[Maldives]]. He first married in 2003 and has three sons from that marriage. He married again to his current wife, Fathimath Moosa, with whom he has a son and a daughter.
Before his political career began, Moosa filled several government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Private Limited. The company was mainly involved in consultancy work in engineering, web design, printing & publishing, composition of business and marketing proposals and reports and many more.
Moosa was practically involved in designing and production of the election campaign material for [[Ilyas Ibrahim]] (brother-in-law of the president Gayyoom) in 1999 who ran against [[Mohamed Nasheed]] (of the opposition) for representing the people of Malé as a member of the parliament. "I worked in Ilyas's last campaign (1999) on the request of Mr. Qasim Ibrahim which later turned out to be a regrettable experience." [http://www.minvanradio.com/do/maldives_statement_21Nov2004_dhivehiobserver.htm]
Since 1999 Moosa has been a consultant to [[Qasim Ibrahim]], former finance minister and leader of Jumhooree Pary, which is part of the current government coalition.[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa/CV%20of%20ASIMoosa.htm] Moosa was also a director of [http://www.horizonfisheries.com/ Horizon Fisheries Private Limited], a company with majority shares owned by Qasim Ibraim and former DRP member of parliament, Ahmed Nashid (ADK).
==Educational background== Moosa completed his secondarys education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. In 1990 he acquired General Certificate of Education with distinction in all subjects, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On [[July 13]], [[1995]] he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] in Bachelor of Engineering with Honours in Mechanical Engineering. Two years later, in 1997, he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring Master of Philosophy (Engineering) in Metallurgy and Materials.
==Political career== In [[september 19]], [[2003]], [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life; end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. International media, namely [[BBC]], covered this unusual event. Moosa gave an interview to BBC on the following month and left Maldives, on [[October 15]], [[2003]], to [[United Kingdom]]. The interview, however, was aired on [[October 17]], [[2003]]. He claims that he left the country because he believes he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on [[November 10]], [[2003]], soon after its official announcement and was a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day to day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview to [[BBC]] (October 2003), he gave several other interviews on different occasions. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government and were usually responded.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on [[September 15]], [[2006]], Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on [[April 11]], [[2005]]. Mr. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in [[London]]. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act. [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/15/wmald15.xml] [http://www.minivannews.com/news/news.php?id=2420]
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.org/ Dhivehiobserver, a satirically political website by Moosa] - ''was banned in the [[Maldives]] until the government changed in November 2008''

That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview to [[BBC]] (October 2003), he gave several other interviews on different occasions. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government and were usually responded.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on [[September 15]], [[2006]], Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on [[April 11]], [[2005]]. Mr. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in [[London]]. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act. [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/15/wmald15.xml] [http://www.minivannews.com/news/news.php?id=2420]
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.org/ Dhivehiobserver, a satirically political website by Moosa] - ''was banned in the [[Maldives]] until the government changed in November 2008''
