{{expert-subject|1=Egypt|reason = some of the recent changes are dubious | date=December 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox political biography | name = Shehab Elabnoudy | image = [[thumbnail]] | fullname = Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa (Sappe') | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1968|11|4}} | birth_place = [[Male']], [[Maldives]]
}} '''Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa''' (born 4 November 1968) is a Maldivian politician and served as Special Envoy of the President Mohamed Nasheed, from March 2009 - Feb 2012. He resigned from his post after the resignation of President Nasheed on 7th February 2012.
== Profile == Mr. Moosa (Sappe') completed his studies in the UK and holds an Honours degree in Mechanical Engineering (B Eng. 1995) from University of Glasgow (UK) and a Masters of Philosophy in Engineering degree in Metallurgy and Materials (M Phil Eng. 1997) from the University of Birmingham (UK). He continued his research work in at Birmingham further towards his PhD but postponed the studies in December 1997.
He worked in Maldives Transport & Construction Company (MTCC) Plc as Senior Engineer for Yanmar Sales and Aftersales Department from 1998 until 2003. He also formed a private consultancy firm in Maldives, A Company Private Limited, in 1999. The operations of the A Company stopped in October 2003, because of his move to the UK fearing arrest due to his criticism of the current Maldivian government in an interview given to the BBC that month, since then he has given many interviews to several international media outlets [Google Search]. 'A Company' carried out several projects for Villa Group, Cyprea, Sun Travels & Tours, DIMMS, MITSUI and several other prominent companies. Services provided by the Company included consultancy work in Engineering, Material Science, Civil Engineering, Law, Marketing and Business as well as Internet and IT.
Mr. Moosa's aim is to play an active role in the economic, social and political development of the Maldives and hopes that the youth and work force will emulate his achievements and aspirations. He believes that education is the key to success, prosperity and better life, the platform for a strong connected society. Mr. Moosa also worked as Director of Business Development and E-Commerce for Sun Travels & Tours Private Limited, one of the largest tour operator in the Maldives and owner of Vilu Reef Beach & Spa and Olhuveli Beach & Spa. He was also a consultant for Villa Shipping & Trading Company, the largest private company in the Maldives, operating more than 5 resorts and a major player in other key economic sectors. He also worked as a consultant for other companies such as Travelin Maldives Private Limited, Aqua Sun Maldives Private Limited, Capital Travel & Tours Private Limited and TBI
Mr. Moosa is the founder and Editor in Chief of Dhivehi Observer News Website - www.dhivehiobserver.com

Mr. Moosa was also elected for two consecutive terms as Co-Chair of the Climate Investment Fund - Strategic Climate Funds in 2010-2011. www.climateinvestmentfunds.org
Mr. Moosa is also a founding member of South Asian Network For Security and Climate Change (SANSaC - www.sansac.org), an international Think Tank.
Mr. Moosa is currently the Chief Commercial Officer of Atoll Paradise Private Limited - www.atollparadise.com, an award winning luxury travel company based in the Maldives.
Dhivehi Observer is famous in the Maldives for the key role it played in exposing the dictatorship of Gayyoom from its launch in 2004. It is also by enlarge credited as a major force in bringing press freedom
Mr. Moosa has published scientific papers in the Journal of Polymer Testing and Journal of Cellular Plastics. His pastimes include reading, writing, philosophy, football, billiards and music.
Mr. Moosa's biography has been recorded in the Marquis Who's Who of Emerging Leaders 2007 (First Edition) as well as in the new edition of 'Who's Who in Asia' in recognition for the work he has done as a journalist, by founding Dhivehi Observer as a major source of news and information for the Maldivian public in general, who have been deprived of real news for many many years by state controlled media.
"The Internet is the medium of choice for people who want to write freely - any educated person with internet access in male' will start the day by reading the Dhivehi Observer (www.dhivehiobserver.com), a tabloid run from exile in the UK by modern-day fold hero Ahmed Moosa, known to one and all as Sappe'. Irreverent, hard-hitting and a self-declared anti-Gayoom site, the Dhivehi Observer is what anyone wanting to know the truth about the Maldives read as a matter of urgency, written as it is by anonymous sources throughout the country. Other great Internet sites include the UK-based Minivan News (www.minivannews.com), which is also a radio station serving the Maldives when it's not jammed." - Lonely Planet Maldives 2006
== Personal life == Ahmed Moosa is married with 5 children.

Mr. Moosa also worked as Director of Business Development and E-Commerce for Sun Travels & Tours Private Limited, one of the largest tour operator in the Maldives and owner of Vilu Reef Beach & Spa and Olhuveli Beach & Spa. He was also a consultant for Villa Shipping & Trading Company, the largest private company in the Maldives, operating more than 5 resorts and a major player in other key economic sectors. He also worked as a consultant for other companies such as Travelin Maldives Private Limited, Aqua Sun Maldives Private Limited, Capital Travel & Tours Private Limited and TBI
Mr. Moosa is the founder and Editor in Chief of Dhivehi Observer News Website - [http://www.dhivehiobserver.com www.dhivehiobserver.com]
Mr. Moosa is a founding member of the Maldivian Democratic Party (MDP), which was formed in exile in November 2003. He was an elected member of the first 15-member General Council of the Party. However, due to his task of being Editor of Dhivehi Observer News website (www.dhivehiobserver.com) he did not hold any elected position in the party but continues to work closely with party leadership on promoting democracy and respect for human rights in the Maldives, both of which have been undermined by the brutal and dictatorial regime of Maumoon Abdul Gayoom since 1978.
Maldivian Democratic Party won the first ever Presidential election held in October 2008.
Mr. Moosa was appointed as President's Envoy for Science & Technology on 11th March 2009. In the wake of the political turmoil and the subsequent resignation of President Nasheed on 7th February 2012, Mr. Moosa followed suit and left the Government.
During his time in the Government, Mr. Moosa represented Maldives at the World Bank Climate Investment Fund, Asia Solar Energey Forum (ADB). Mr. Moosa was also elected for two consecutive terms as Co-Chair of the Climate Investment Fund - Strategic Climate Funds in 2010-2011. www.climateinvestmentfunds.org
Mr. Moosa is also a founding member of South Asian Network For Security and Climate Change (SANSaC - www.sansac.org), an international Think Tank.
Mr. Moosa is currently the Chief Commercial Officer of Atoll Paradise Private Limited - www.atollparadise.com, an award winning luxury travel company based in the Maldives.
Dhivehi Observer is famous in the Maldives for the key role it played in exposing the dictatorship of Gayyoom from its launch in 2004. It is also by enlarge credited as a major force in bringing press freedom
Mr. Moosa has published scientific papers in the Journal of Polymer Testing and Journal of Cellular Plastics. His pastimes include reading, writing, philosophy, football, billiards and music.
Mr. Moosa's biography has been recorded in the Marquis Who's Who of Emerging Leaders 2007 (First Edition) as well as in the new edition of 'Who's Who in Asia' in recognition for the work he has done as a journalist, by founding Dhivehi Observer as a major source of news and information for the Maldivian public in general, who have been deprived of real news for many many years by state controlled media.
"The Internet is the medium of choice for people who want to write freely - any educated person with internet access in male' will start the day by reading the Dhivehi Observer (www.dhivehiobserver.com), a tabloid run from exile in the UK by modern-day fold hero Ahmed Moosa, known to one and all as Sappe'. Irreverent, hard-hitting and a self-declared anti-Gayoom site, the Dhivehi Observer is what anyone wanting to know the truth about the Maldives read as a matter of urgency, written as it is by anonymous sources throughout the country. Other great Internet sites include the UK-based Minivan News (www.minivannews.com), which is also a radio station serving the Maldives when it's not jammed." - Lonely Planet Maldives 2006
== Personal life == Ahmed Moosa is married with 5 children.
== References == {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
== External links == * [http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa] [http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa] Dhivehi Observer News Website * 13 November 2010, Press Releases [http://Maldives%20Elected%20Co-Chair%20of%20World%20Bank´s%20Strategic%20Climate%20Fund%20Governing%20Committee http://www.presidencymaldives.gov.mv/Index.aspx?lid=11&dcid=1623] * 08 August 2009, Press Releases [http://NCIT%20holds%20a%20leadership%20retreat%20on%20e-governance%20in%20collaboration%20with%20UNU%20and%20the%20President’s%20Office http://www.presidencymaldives.gov.mv/Index.aspx?lid=11&dcid=458] * 18 November 2011, Press Releases [http://Maldives%20participate%20in%20the%201st%20UN%20Expert%20Meeting%20on%20Human%20Space%20Technology http://www.presidencymaldives.gov.mv/Index.aspx?lid=11&dcid=6291]

revision.text:
'''Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa''' (born 4 November 1968) is a Maldivian politician and served as Special Envoy of the President Mohamed Nasheed, from March 2009 - Feb 2012. He resigned from his post after the resignation of President Nasheed on 7th February 2012.
== Profile == Mr. Moosa (Sappe') completed his studies in the UK and holds an Honours degree in Mechanical Engineering (B Eng. 1995) from University of Glasgow (UK) and a Masters of Philosophy in Engineering degree in Metallurgy and Materials (M Phil Eng. 1997) from the University of Birmingham (UK). He continued his research work in at Birmingham further towards his PhD but postponed the studies in December 1997.
He worked in Maldives Transport & Construction Company (MTCC) Plc as Senior Engineer for Yanmar Sales and Aftersales Department from 1998 until 2003. He also formed a private consultancy firm in Maldives, A Company Private Limited, in 1999. The operations of the A Company stopped in October 2003, because of his move to the UK fearing arrest due to his criticism of the current Maldivian government in an interview given to the BBC that month, since then he has given many interviews to several international media outlets [Google Search]. 'A Company' carried out several projects for Villa Group, Cyprea, Sun Travels & Tours, DIMMS, MITSUI and several other prominent companies. Services provided by the Company included consultancy work in Engineering, Material Science, Civil Engineering, Law, Marketing and Business as well as Internet and IT.
Mr. Moosa's aim is to play an active role in the economic, social and political development of the Maldives and hopes that the youth and work force will emulate his achievements and aspirations. He believes that education is the key to success, prosperity and better life, the platform for a strong connected society. Mr. Moosa also worked as Director of Business Development and E-Commerce for Sun Travels & Tours Private Limited, one of the largest tour operator in the Maldives and owner of Vilu Reef Beach & Spa and Olhuveli Beach & Spa. He was also a consultant for Villa Shipping & Trading Company, the largest private company in the Maldives, operating more than 5 resorts and a major player in other key economic sectors. He also worked as a consultant for other companies such as Travelin Maldives Private Limited, Aqua Sun Maldives Private Limited, Capital Travel & Tours Private Limited and TBI
Mr. Moosa is the founder and Editor in Chief of Dhivehi Observer News Website - [http://www.dhivehiobserver.com www.dhivehiobserver.com]

However, due to his task of being Editor of Dhivehi Observer News website (www.dhivehiobserver.com) he did not hold any elected position in the party but continues to work closely with party leadership on promoting democracy and respect for human rights in the Maldives, both of which have been undermined by the brutal and dictatorial regime of Maumoon Abdul Gayoom since 1978.
Maldivian Democratic Party won the first ever Presidential election held in October 2008.
Mr. Moosa was appointed as President's Envoy for Science & Technology on 11th March 2009. In the wake of the political turmoil and the subsequent resignation of President Nasheed on 7th February 2012, Mr. Moosa followed suit and left the Government.
During his time in the Government, Mr. Moosa represented Maldives at the World Bank Climate Investment Fund, Asia Solar Energey Forum (ADB). Mr. Moosa was also elected for two consecutive terms as Co-Chair of the Climate Investment Fund - Strategic Climate Funds in 2010-2011. www.climateinvestmentfunds.org
Mr. Moosa is also a founding member of South Asian Network For Security and Climate Change (SANSaC - www.sansac.org), an international Think Tank.
Mr. Moosa is currently the Chief Commercial Officer of Atoll Paradise Private Limited - www.atollparadise.com, an award winning luxury travel company based in the Maldives.
Dhivehi Observer is famous in the Maldives for the key role it played in exposing the dictatorship of Gayyoom from its launch in 2004. It is also by enlarge credited as a major force in bringing press freedom
Mr. Moosa has published scientific papers in the Journal of Polymer Testing and Journal of Cellular Plastics. His pastimes include reading, writing, philosophy, football, billiards and music.
Mr. Moosa's biography has been recorded in the Marquis Who's Who of Emerging Leaders 2007 (First Edition) as well as in the new edition of 'Who's Who in Asia' in recognition for the work he has done as a journalist, by founding Dhivehi Observer as a major source of news and information for the Maldivian public in general, who have been deprived of real news for many many years by state controlled media.
"The Internet is the medium of choice for people who want to write freely - any educated person with internet access in male' will start the day by reading the Dhivehi Observer (www.dhivehiobserver.com), a tabloid run from exile in the UK by modern-day fold hero Ahmed Moosa, known to one and all as Sappe'. Irreverent, hard-hitting and a self-declared anti-Gayoom site, the Dhivehi Observer is what anyone wanting to know the truth about the Maldives read as a matter of urgency, written as it is by anonymous sources throughout the country. Other great Internet sites include the UK-based Minivan News (www.minivannews.com), which is also a radio station serving the Maldives when it's not jammed." - Lonely Planet Maldives 2006
== Personal life == Ahmed Moosa is married with 5 children.

revision.comment: Revert. The current version is the right person, but a spam / CV. The last version is the wrong person after vandalism, so go back to the last clean version
revision.text:
Moosa is the President's Envoy for Science and Technology. He was appointed on 11 March 2009.<ref>[http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/maldives-aims-to-become-first-carbonneutral-country-1644907.html ''The Independent'' "Maldives aims to become first carbon-neutral country", 14 March 2009]</ref>
Moosa is amongst those who campaigned for democracy and human rights which led to the end of the 30 year rule of [[Gayoom]] in November 2008. He is the founder and editor in chief of the news website Dhivehi Observer.<ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com ''Dhivehi Observer'']</ref><ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/aboutus.html ''Dhivehi Observer:About Us'']</ref>
Moosa is a senior member of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] and was elected to its first General Council. He was a widely outspoken critic of the former president [[Gayoom]]. He lived in self-proclaimed [[exile]] in the [[United Kingdom]] with his family from 2003 - 2008. The opposition Coalition won the Presidential Election held in October 2008.
Moosa is normally resident in [[Glasgow]], United Kingdom.{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}}
==Early and personal life== Moosa was born in [[Malé]], [[Maldives]]. He first married in 2003 and has three sons from that marriage. He married secondly Fathimath Moosa, with whom he has a son and a daughter.
Before his political career began, Moosa filled several government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Pvt Ltd. The company was mainly involved in consultancy work in engineering, web design, printing and publishing, composition of business and marketing proposals and reports.
Moosa was practically involved in designing and production of the election campaign material for [[Ilyas Ibrahim]] (brother-in-law of the president Gayyoom) in 1999 who ran against [[Mohamed Nasheed]] (of the opposition) for representing the people of [[Malé]] as a member of the parliament. "I worked in Ilyas's last campaign (1999) on the request of Mr. Qasim Ibrahim which later turned out to be a regrettable experience." [http://www.minvanradio.com/do/maldives_statement_21Nov2004_dhivehiobserver.htm]
Since 1999 Moosa has been a consultant to [[Qasim Ibrahim]], former finance minister and leader of the [[Jumhooree Party]], which is part of the current government coalition.<ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa/CV%20of%20ASIMoosa.htm ''Dhivehi Observer'' Ahmed S. I. Moosa, Personal Details]</ref> Moosa was also a director of [http://www.horizonfisheries.com/ Horizon Fisheries Private Limited], a company with majority shares owned by Qasim Ibraim and former DRP member of parliament, Ahmed Nashid (ADK).
==Educational background== Moosa completed his secondary education at the [[Malé English School]], Malé. In 1990 he acquired General Certificate of Education with distinction in all subjects, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On 13 July 1995 he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with a B. Eng with honours in mechanical engineering. Two years later, in 1997, he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring PhD (Engineering) in metallurgy and materials.
==Political career== In 19 September 2003, [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life; end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. The [[BBC]], covered this event and Moosa gave an interview to the BBC the following month and left Maldives, on 15 October 2003, to [[United Kingdom]]. The interview was aired on 17 October 2003. He says he left the country because he believed he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said Sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on 10 November 2003, soon after its official announcement and was a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day to day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview with the BBC, he gave several other interviews. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on 15 September 2006, Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on 11 April 2005. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in London. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act.<ref>[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/15/wmald15.xml ''The Telegraph'' "UK police warn wife of Maldives policeman over threat", 15 September 2006]</ref>
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/ Dhivehiobserver, a satirically political website by Moosa]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2011}}

That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.

Moosa is a senior member of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] and was elected to its first General Council. He was a widely outspoken critic of the former president [[Gayoom]]. He lived in self-proclaimed [[exile]] in the [[United Kingdom]] with his family from 2003 - 2008. The opposition Coalition won the Presidential Election held in October 2008.
Moosa is normally resident in [[Glasgow]], United Kingdom. </ref><ref>[http://www.scotland.gov.uk/News/Releases/2009/12/1111143 ''Scotland-Maldives Partnership", 11 December 2009]</ref>
==Early and personal life== Moosa was born in [[Malé]], [[Maldives]]. He first married in 2003 and has three sons from that marriage. He married secondly Fathimath Moosa, with whom he has a son and a daughter.
Before his political career began, Moosa filled several government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Pvt Ltd. The company was mainly involved in consultancy work in engineering, web design, printing and publishing, composition of business and marketing proposals and reports.
Moosa was practically involved in designing and production of the election campaign material for [[Ilyas Ibrahim]] (brother-in-law of the president Gayyoom) in 1999 who ran against [[Mohamed Nasheed]] (of the opposition) for representing the people of [[Malé]] as a member of the parliament. "I worked in Ilyas's last campaign (1999) on the request of Mr. Qasim Ibrahim which later turned out to be a regrettable experience." [http://www.minvanradio.com/do/maldives_statement_21Nov2004_dhivehiobserver.htm]
Since 1999 Moosa has been a consultant to [[Qasim Ibrahim]], Chairman of Villa Shipping and Trading Company, the largest private company in the Maldives. He is the Leaderof the [[Jumhooree Party]], which is part of the current government coalition.<ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa/CV%20of%20ASIMoosa.htm ''Dhivehi Observer'' Ahmed S. I. Moosa, Personal Details]</ref> Moosa was also a director of [http://www.horizonfisheries.com/ Horizon Fisheries Private Limited], a company with majority shares owned by Qasim Ibraim and former DRP member of parliament, Ahmed Nashid (ADK).
==Educational background== Moosa completed his secondary education at the [[Malé English School]], Malé. In 1990 he acquired General Certificate of Education with distinction in all subjects, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On 13 July 1995 he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with a B. Eng with honours in mechanical engineering. Two years later, in 1997, he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring PhD (Engineering) in metallurgy and materials.
==Political career== In 19 September 2003, [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life; end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. The [[BBC]], covered this event and Moosa gave an interview to the BBC the following month and left Maldives, on 15 October 2003, to [[United Kingdom]]. The interview was aired on 17 October 2003. He says he left the country because he believed he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said Sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on 10 November 2003, soon after its official announcement and was a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day to day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview with the BBC, he gave several other interviews. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on 15 September 2006, Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on 11 April 2005. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in London. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act.<ref>[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/15/wmald15.xml ''The Telegraph'' "UK police warn wife of Maldives policeman over threat", 15 September 2006]</ref>
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/ Dhivehiobserver, a satirically political website by Moosa] **[http://www.facebook.com/asimoosa Facebook Page]

revision.text:
[[File:Ahmed Moosa.jpg|thumb|Ahmed Moosa - Sappe']]Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa, famously known as ''Sappe''' was the President's Envoy for Science and Technology of the first democratically elected Government of the Maldives. He was appointed on 11 March 2009. He resigned from the Government on 9 February 2012, soon after President Nasheed's Government was allegedly overthrown by the incumbent President Mohamed Waheed two days earlier.<ref>[http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/maldives-aims-to-become-first-carbonneutral-country-1644907.html ''The Independent'' "Maldives aims to become first carbon-neutral country", 14 March 2009]</ref><ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2012/feb/07/mohamed-nasheed-resigns-maldives-president ''The Guarding'' "Mohamed Nasheed resigns as Maldives President", 7 February 2012]</ref>
Moosa is amongst those who campaigned for democracy and human rights which led to the end of the 30 year rule of [[Gayoom]] in November 2008. He is the founder and editor in chief of the news website Dhivehi Observer.<ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com ''Dhivehi Observer'']</ref><ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/aboutus.html ''Dhivehi Observer:About Us'']</ref>
Moosa is a senior member of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] and was elected to its first General Council. He was a widely outspoken critic of the former president [[Gayoom]]. He lived in self-proclaimed [[exile]] in the [[United Kingdom]] with his family from 2003 - 2008. The opposition Coalition won the Presidential Election held in October 2008.
Moosa is normally resident in [[Glasgow]], United Kingdom.<ref>[http://www.scotland.gov.uk/News/Releases/2009/12/1111143 ''Scotland-Maldives Partnership", 11 December 2009]</ref>
==Early and personal life== Moosa was born in [[Malé]], [[Maldives]]. He first married in 2003 and has three sons from that marriage. He married secondly Fathimath Moosa, with whom he has a son and a daughter.
Before his political career began, Moosa filled several government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Pvt Ltd. The company was mainly involved in consultancy work in engineering, web design, printing and publishing, composition of business and marketing proposals and reports.
Moosa was practically involved in designing and production of the election campaign material for [[Ilyas Ibrahim]] (brother-in-law of the president Gayyoom) in 1999 who ran against [[Mohamed Nasheed]] (of the opposition) for representing the people of [[Malé]] as a member of the parliament. "I worked in Ilyas's last campaign (1999) on the request of Mr. Qasim Ibrahim which later turned out to be a regrettable experience." [http://www.minvanradio.com/do/maldives_statement_21Nov2004_dhivehiobserver.htm]
Since 1999 Moosa has been a consultant to [[Qasim Ibrahim]], Chairman of Villa Shipping and Trading Company, the largest private company in the Maldives. He is the Leaderof the [[Jumhooree Party]], which is part of the current government coalition.<ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa/CV%20of%20ASIMoosa.htm ''Dhivehi Observer'' Ahmed S. I. Moosa, Personal Details]</ref> Moosa was also a director of [http://www.horizonfisheries.com/ Horizon Fisheries Private Limited], a company with majority shares owned by Qasim Ibraim and former DRP member of parliament, Ahmed Nashid (ADK).
==Educational background== Moosa completed his secondary education at the [[Malé English School]], Malé. In 1990 he acquired General Certificate of Education with distinction in all subjects, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On 13 July 1995 he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with a B. Eng with honours in mechanical engineering. Two years later, in 1997, he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring PhD (Engineering) in metallurgy and materials.
==Political career== In 19 September 2003, [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life; end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. The [[BBC]], covered this event and Moosa gave an interview to the BBC the following month and left Maldives, on 15 October 2003, to [[United Kingdom]]. The interview was aired on 17 October 2003. He says he left the country because he believed he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said Sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on 10 November 2003, soon after its official announcement and was a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day to day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview with the BBC, he gave several other interviews. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on 15 September 2006, Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on 11 April 2005. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in London. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act.<ref>[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/15/wmald15.xml ''The Telegraph'' "UK police warn wife of Maldives policeman over threat", 15 September 2006]</ref>
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/ Dhivehiobserver, a satirically political website by Moosa] **[http://www.facebook.com/asimoosa Facebook Page]

Two years later, in 1997, he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring PhD (Engineering) in metallurgy and materials.
==Political career== In 19 September 2003, [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life; end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. The [[BBC]], covered this event and Moosa gave an interview to the BBC the following month and left Maldives, on 15 October 2003, to [[United Kingdom]]. The interview was aired on 17 October 2003. He says he left the country because he believed he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said Sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on 10 November 2003, soon after its official announcement and was a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day-to-day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview with the BBC, he gave several other interviews. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on 15 September 2006, Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on 11 April 2005. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in London. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act.<ref>[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/15/wmald15.xml ''The Telegraph'' "UK police warn wife of Maldives policeman over threat", 15 September 2006]</ref>
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/ Dhivehiobserver, a satirically political website by Moosa] **[http://www.facebook.com/asimoosa Facebook Page]

[[File:Ahmed Moosa.jpg|thumb|Ahmed Moosa - Sappe']]Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa, famously known as ''Sappe''' was the President's Envoy for Science and Technology of the first democratically elected Government of the Maldives. He was appointed on 11 March 2009. He resigned from the Government on 9 February 2012, soon after President Nasheed's Government was allegedly overthrown by the incumbent President Mohamed Waheed two days earlier. .<ref>[http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/maldives-aims-to-become-first-carbonneutral-country-1644907.html ''The Independent'' "Maldives aims to become first carbon-neutral country", 14 March 2009]</ref><ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2012/feb/07/mohamed-nasheed-resigns-maldives-president ''The Guarding'' "Mohamed Nasheed resigns as Maldives President", 7 February 2012]</ref>
Moosa is amongst those who campaigned for democracy and human rights which led to the end of the 30 year rule of [[Gayoom]] in November 2008. He is the founder and editor in chief of the news website Dhivehi Observer.<ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com ''Dhivehi Observer'']</ref><ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/aboutus.html ''Dhivehi Observer:About Us'']</ref>
Moosa is a senior member of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] and was elected to its first General Council. He was a widely outspoken critic of the former president [[Gayoom]]. He lived in self-proclaimed [[exile]] in the [[United Kingdom]] with his family from 2003 - 2008. The opposition Coalition won the Presidential Election held in October 2008.
Moosa is normally resident in [[Glasgow]], United Kingdom.<ref>[http://www.scotland.gov.uk/News/Releases/2009/12/1111143 ''Scotland-Maldives Partnership", 11 December 2009]</ref>
==Early and personal life== Moosa was born in [[Malé]], [[Maldives]]. He first married in 2003 and has three sons from that marriage. He married secondly Fathimath Moosa, with whom he has a son and a daughter.
Before his political career began, Moosa filled several government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Pvt Ltd. The company was mainly involved in consultancy work in engineering, web design, printing and publishing, composition of business and marketing proposals and reports.
Moosa was practically involved in designing and production of the election campaign material for [[Ilyas Ibrahim]] (brother-in-law of the president Gayyoom) in 1999 who ran against [[Mohamed Nasheed]] (of the opposition) for representing the people of [[Malé]] as a member of the parliament. "I worked in Ilyas's last campaign (1999) on the request of Mr. Qasim Ibrahim which later turned out to be a regrettable experience." [http://www.minvanradio.com/do/maldives_statement_21Nov2004_dhivehiobserver.htm]
Since 1999 Moosa has been a consultant to [[Qasim Ibrahim]], Chairman of Villa Shipping and Trading Company, the largest private company in the Maldives. He is the Leaderof the [[Jumhooree Party]], which is part of the current government coalition.<ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa/CV%20of%20ASIMoosa.htm ''Dhivehi Observer'' Ahmed S. I. Moosa, Personal Details]</ref> Moosa was also a director of [http://www.horizonfisheries.com/ Horizon Fisheries Private Limited], a company with majority shares owned by Qasim Ibraim and former DRP member of parliament, Ahmed Nashid (ADK).
==Educational background== Moosa completed his secondary education at the [[Malé English School]], Malé. In 1990 he acquired General Certificate of Education with distinction in all subjects, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On 13 July 1995 he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with a B. Eng with honours in mechanical engineering. Two years later, in 1997, he graduated at [[University of ruggy]] acquiring PhD (engineering) in metallurgy and materials.
==Political career== In 19 September 2003, [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life; end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. The [[BBC]], covered this event and Moosa gave an interview to the BBC the following month and left Maldives, on 15 October 2003, to [[United Kingdom]]. The interview was aired on 17 October 2003. After his initial interview with the BBC, he gave several other interviews. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on 15 September 2006, Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on 11 April 2005. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in London. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act.<ref>[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/15/wmald15.xml ''The Telegraph'' "UK police warn wife of Maldives policeman over threat", 15 September 2006]</ref>

Moosa is a senior member of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] and was elected to its first General Council. He was a widely outspoken critic of the former president [[Gayoom]]. He lived in self-proclaimed [[exile]] in the [[United Kingdom]] with his family from 2003 - 2008. The opposition Coalition won the Presidential Election held in October 2008.
Moosa is normally resident in [[Glasgow]], United Kingdom.<ref>[http://www.scotland.gov.uk/News/Releases/2009/12/1111143 ''Scotland-Maldives Partnership", 11 December 2009]</ref>
==Early and personal life== Moosa was born in [[Malé]], [[Maldives]]. He first married in 2003 and has three sons Adam, Michael and Daniel from that marriage. He married secondly Fathimath Moosa, with whom he has a son and a daughter.
Before his political career began, Moosa filled several government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Pvt Ltd. The company was mainly involved in consultancy work in engineering, web design, printing and publishing, composition of business and marketing proposals and reports.
Moosa was practically involved in designing and production of the election campaign material for [[Ilyas Ibrahim]] (brother-in-law of the president Gayyoom) in 1999 who ran against [[Mohamed Nasheed]] (of the opposition) for representing the people of [[Malé]] as a member of the parliament. "I worked in Ilyas's last campaign (1999) on the request of Mr. Qasim Ibrahim which later turned out to be a regrettable experience." [http://www.minvanradio.com/do/maldives_statement_21Nov2004_dhivehiobserver.htm]
Since 1999 Moosa has been a consultant to [[Qasim Ibrahim]], Chairman of Villa Shipping and Trading Company, the largest private company in the Maldives. He is the Leaderof the [[Jumhooree Party]], which is part of the current government coalition.<ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa/CV%20of%20ASIMoosa.htm ''Dhivehi Observer'' Ahmed S. I. Moosa, Personal Details]</ref> Moosa was also a director of [http://www.horizonfisheries.com/ Horizon Fisheries Private Limited], a company with majority shares owned by Qasim Ibraim and former DRP member of parliament, Ahmed Nashid (ADK).
==Educational background== Moosa completed his secondary education at the [[Malé English School]], Malé. In 1990 he acquired General Certificate of Education with distinction in all subjects, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On 13 July 1995 he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with a B. Eng with honours in mechanical engineering. Two years later, in 1997, he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring PhD (Engineering) in metallurgy and materials.
==Political career== In 19 September 2003, [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life; end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. The [[BBC]], covered this event and Moosa gave an interview to the BBC the following month and left Maldives, on 15 October 2003, to [[United Kingdom]]. The interview was aired on 17 October 2003. He says he left the country because he believed he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said Sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on 10 November 2003, soon after its official announcement and was a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day-to-day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview with the BBC, he gave several other interviews. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on 15 September 2006, Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on 11 April 2005. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in London. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act.<ref>[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/15/wmald15.xml ''The Telegraph'' "UK police warn wife of Maldives policeman over threat", 15 September 2006]</ref>
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/ Dhivehiobserver, a satirically political website by Moosa] **[http://www.facebook.com/asimoosa Facebook Page]

According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on 15 September 2006, Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on 11 April 2005. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in London. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act.<ref>[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/15/wmald15.xml ''The Telegraph'' "UK police warn wife of Maldives policeman over threat", 15 September 2006]</ref>

{{DEFAULTSORT:Moosa, Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim}} [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Maldivian Muslims]] [[Category:Maldivian democracy activists]] [[Category:Maldivian Democratic Party politicians]] [[Category:People from Malé]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Birmingham]]

[[File:Ahmed Moosa.jpg|thumb|Ahmed Moosa - Sappe']]Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa, famously known as ''Sappe''' was the President's Envoy for Science and Technology of the first democratically elected Government of the Maldives. He was appointed on 11 March 2009. He resigned from the Government on 9 February 2012, soon after President Nasheed's Government was allegedly overthrown by the incumbent President Mohamed Waheed two days earlier. .<ref>[http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/maldives-aims-to-become-first-carbonneutral-country-1644907.html ''The Independent'' "Maldives aims to become first carbon-neutral country", 14 March 2009]</ref><ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2012/feb/07/mohamed-nasheed-resigns-maldives-president ''The Guarding'' "Mohamed Nasheed resigns as Maldives President", 7 February 2012]</ref>
Moosa is amongst those who campaigned for democracy and human rights which led to the end of the 30 year rule of [[Gayoom]] in November 2008. He is the founder and editor in chief of the news website Dhivehi Observer.<ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com ''Dhivehi Observer'']</ref><ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/aboutus.html ''Dhivehi Observer:About Us'']</ref>
Moosa is a senior member of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] and was elected to its first General Council. He was a widely outspoken critic of the former president [[Gayoom]]. He lived in self-proclaimed [[exile]] in the [[United Kingdom]] with his family from 2003 - 2008. The opposition Coalition won the Presidential Election held in October 2008.
Moosa is normally resident in [[Glasgow]], United Kingdom.<ref>[http://www.scotland.gov.uk/News/Releases/2009/12/1111143 ''Scotland-Maldives Partnership", 11 December 2009]</ref>
==Early and personal life== Moosa was born in [[Malé]], [[Maldives]]. He first married in 1995 and has three sons Adam, Michael and Daniel(the best) from that marriage. He married secondly Fathimath Moosa, with whom he has a son and a daughter.
Before his political career began, Moosa filled several government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Pvt Ltd. The company was mainly involved in consultancy work in engineering, web design, printing and publishing, composition of business and marketing proposals and reports.
Moosa was practically involved in designing and production of the election campaign material for [[Ilyas Ibrahim]] (brother-in-law of the president Gayyoom) in 1999 who ran against [[Mohamed Nasheed]] (of the opposition) for representing the people of [[Malé]] as a member of the parliament. "I worked in Ilyas's last campaign (1999) on the request of Mr. Qasim Ibrahim which later turned out to be a regrettable experience." [http://www.minvanradio.com/do/maldives_statement_21Nov2004_dhivehiobserver.htm]
Since 1999 Moosa has been a consultant to [[Qasim Ibrahim]], Chairman of Villa Shipping and Trading Company, the largest private company in the Maldives. He is the Leaderof the [[Jumhooree Party]], which is part of the current government coalition.<ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa/CV%20of%20ASIMoosa.htm ''Dhivehi Observer'' Ahmed S. I. Moosa, Personal Details]</ref> Moosa was also a director of [http://www.horizonfisheries.com/ Horizon Fisheries Private Limited], a company with majority shares owned by Qasim Ibraim and former DRP member of parliament, Ahmed Nashid (ADK).
==Educational background== Moosa completed his secondary education at the [[Malé English School]], Malé. In 1990 he acquired General Certificate of Education with distinction in all subjects, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On 13 July 1995 he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with a B. Eng with honours in mechanical engineering. Two years later, in 1997, he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring PhD (Engineering) in metallurgy and materials.
==Political career== On 19 September 2003, [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life; end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. The [[BBC]], covered this event and Moosa gave an interview to the BBC the following month and left Maldives, on 15 October 2003, to [[United Kingdom]]. The interview was aired on 17 October 2003. He says he left the country because he believed he would be in danger if remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said Sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on 10 November 2003, soon after its official announcement and was a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day-to-day operations of the party for two reasons. That is; MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview with the BBC, he gave several other interviews. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on 15 September 2006, Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on 11 April 2005. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in London. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act.<ref>[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/15/wmald15.xml ''The Telegraph'' "UK police warn wife of Maldives policeman over threat", 15 September 2006]</ref>
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/ Dhivehiobserver, a satirically political website by Moosa] **[http://www.facebook.com/asimoosa Facebook Page]

==Political career== On 19 September 2003, [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life, the end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. The [[BBC]] covered this event and Moosa gave an interview to the BBC the following month and left Maldives, on 15 October 2003, to the [[United Kingdom]]. The interview was aired on 17 October 2003. He says he left the country because he believed he would be in danger if he remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said Sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on 10 November 2003, soon after its official announcement and was a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day-to-day operations of the party for two reasons. That is, MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview with the BBC, he gave several other interviews. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on 15 September 2006, Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on 11 April 2005. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in London. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act.<ref>[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/15/wmald15.xml ''The Telegraph'' "UK police warn wife of Maldives policeman over threat", 15 September 2006]</ref>
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/ Dhivehiobserver, a satirically political website by Moosa] **[http://www.facebook.com/asimoosa Facebook Page]

[[File:Ahmed Moosa.jpg|thumb|Ahmed Moosa - Sappe']] '''Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa''', also known as '''Sappé''', is a Maldivian editor-in-chief and politican who served as the first Envoy for Science and Technology to be appointed by the first democratically elected [[president of the Maldives]], [[Mohamed Nasheed]]. He was appointed to his position on 11 March 2009 and resigned from the Maldivian government on 9 February 2012, soon after President Nasheed's government was allegedly overthrown by the incumbent President [[Mohammed Waheed Hassan]] two days earlier.<ref>[http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/maldives-aims-to-become-first-carbonneutral-country-1644907.html ''The Independent'' "Maldives aims to become first carbon-neutral country", 14 March 2009]</ref><ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2012/feb/07/mohamed-nasheed-resigns-maldives-president ''The Guarding'' "Mohamed Nasheed resigns as Maldives President", 7 February 2012]</ref> Moosa is amongst those who campaigned for democracy and [[human rights]] which led to the end of the 30 year rule of [[Gayoom]] in November 2008. He is the founder and [[editor-in-chief]] of the news website ''Dhivehi Observer''.<ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com ''Dhivehi Observer'']</ref><ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/aboutus.html ''Dhivehi Observer:About Us'']</ref>
Moosa is a senior member of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] and was elected to its first General Council. He was a widely outspoken critic of the former president [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]]. He lived in self-proclaimed [[exile]] in the [[United Kingdom]] with his family from 2003-2008. The opposition Coalition won the [[Maldivian presidential election, 2008|Presidential Election held in October 2008]].
Moosa resides in [[Glasgow]], United Kingdom as of 2009.<ref>[http://www.scotland.gov.uk/News/Releases/2009/12/1111143 ''Scotland-Maldives Partnership", 11 December 2009]</ref>
==Early and personal life== Moosa was born in [[Malé]], [[Maldives]]. He first married in 1995 and had three sons from that marriage: Adam, Michael and Daniel. He married secondly Fathimath Moosa, with whom he had a son and a daughter.
Before his political career began, Moosa filled several government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Pvt Ltd. The company was mainly involved in consultancy work in engineering, web design, printing and publishing, composition of business and marketing proposals and reports.
Moosa was practically involved in designing and production of the election campaign material for [[Ilyas Ibrahim]] (brother-in-law of the president Gayyoom) in 1999 who ran against [[Mohamed Nasheed]] (of the opposition) for representing the people of [[Malé]] as a member of the parliament. "I worked in Ilyas's last campaign (1999) on the request of Mr. Qasim Ibrahim which later turned out to be a regrettable experience." [http://www.minvanradio.com/do/maldives_statement_21Nov2004_dhivehiobserver.htm]
Since 1999 Moosa has been a consultant to [[Qasim Ibrahim]], Chairman of Villa Shipping and Trading Company, the largest private company in the Maldives. He is the leader of the [[Jumhooree Party]], which is part of the current government coalition.<ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa/CV%20of%20ASIMoosa.htm ''Dhivehi Observer'' Ahmed S. I. Moosa, Personal Details]</ref> Moosa was also a director of [http://www.horizonfisheries.com/ Horizon Fisheries Private Limited], a company with majority shares owned by Qasim Ibraim and former DRP member of parliament, Ahmed Nashid (ADK).
==Education== Moosa completed his secondary education at the [[Malé English School]], Malé. In 1990 he acquired General Certificate of Education with distinction in all subjects, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On 13 July 1995 he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with a B. Eng with honours in mechanical engineering. Two years later, in 1997, he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring PhD (Engineering) in metallurgy and materials.
==Political career== On 19 September 2003, [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life, the end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. The [[BBC]] covered this event and Moosa gave an interview to the BBC the following month and left Maldives, on 15 October 2003, to the [[United Kingdom]]. The interview was aired on 17 October 2003. He says he left the country because he believed he would be in danger if he remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said Sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on 10 November 2003, soon after its official announcement and was a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day-to-day operations of the party for two reasons. That is, MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview with the BBC, he gave several other interviews. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on 15 September 2006, Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on 11 April 2005. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in London. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act.<ref>[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/15/wmald15.xml ''The Telegraph'' "UK police warn wife of Maldives policeman over threat", 15 September 2006]</ref>

{{Infobox officeholder | honorific-prefix = | name = Ahmed Moosa | native_name = | native_name_lang = | honorific-suffix = | image = Ahmed Moosa.jpg | image_size = | smallimage = <!--If this is specified, "image" should not be.--> | alt = | caption = | order = | office = Envoy for Science and Technology of the Maldives | term_start = 11 March 2009 | term_end = 9 February 2012 | president = [[Mohamed Nasheed]] | vice_president = [[Mohammed Waheed Hassan]] | predecessor = | successor = | birth_name = Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa | birth_place = [[Malé]], [[Maldives]] | nationality = Maldivian | party = [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] | spouse = | children = 5 | residence = [[Glasgow]], United Kingdom | education = [[University of Glasgow]] <small>(1995; B. Eng.)</small> | occupation = [[Editor-in-chief]] }}
'''Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa''', also known as '''Sappé''', is a Maldivian editor-in-chief and politican who served as the first Envoy for Science and Technology to be appointed by the first democratically elected [[president of the Maldives]], [[Mohamed Nasheed]]. He was appointed to his position on 11 March 2009 and resigned from the Maldivian government on 9 February 2012, soon after President Nasheed's government was allegedly overthrown by the incumbent President [[Mohammed Waheed Hassan]] two days earlier.<ref>[http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/maldives-aims-to-become-first-carbonneutral-country-1644907.html ''The Independent'' "Maldives aims to become first carbon-neutral country", 14 March 2009]</ref><ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2012/feb/07/mohamed-nasheed-resigns-maldives-president ''The Guarding'' "Mohamed Nasheed resigns as Maldives President", 7 February 2012]</ref> Moosa is amongst those who campaigned for democracy and [[human rights]] which led to the end of the 30 year rule of [[Gayoom]] in November 2008. He is the founder and [[editor-in-chief]] of the news website ''Dhivehi Observer''.<ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com ''Dhivehi Observer'']</ref><ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/aboutus.html ''Dhivehi Observer:About Us'']</ref>
Moosa is a senior member of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] and was elected to its first General Council. He was a widely outspoken critic of the former president [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]]. He lived in self-proclaimed [[exile]] in the [[United Kingdom]] with his family from 2003-2008. The opposition Coalition won the [[Maldivian presidential election, 2008|Presidential Election held in October 2008]].
Moosa resides in [[Glasgow]], United Kingdom as of 2009.<ref>[http://www.scotland.gov.uk/News/Releases/2009/12/1111143 ''Scotland-Maldives Partnership", 11 December 2009]</ref>
==Early and personal life== Moosa was born in [[Malé]], [[Maldives]]. He first married in 1995 and had three sons from that marriage: Adam, Michael and Daniel. He married secondly Fathimath Moosa, with whom he had a son and a daughter.
Before his political career began, Moosa filled several government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Pvt Ltd. The company was mainly involved in consultancy work in engineering, web design, printing and publishing, composition of business and marketing proposals and reports.
Moosa was practically involved in designing and production of the election campaign material for [[Ilyas Ibrahim]] (brother-in-law of the president Gayyoom) in 1999 who ran against [[Mohamed Nasheed]] (of the opposition) for representing the people of [[Malé]] as a member of the parliament. "I worked in Ilyas's last campaign (1999) on the request of Mr. Qasim Ibrahim which later turned out to be a regrettable experience." [http://www.minvanradio.com/do/maldives_statement_21Nov2004_dhivehiobserver.htm]
Since 1999 Moosa has been a consultant to [[Qasim Ibrahim]], Chairman of Villa Shipping and Trading Company, the largest private company in the Maldives. He is the leader of the [[Jumhooree Party]], which is part of the current government coalition.<ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa/CV%20of%20ASIMoosa.htm ''Dhivehi Observer'' Ahmed S. I. Moosa, Personal Details]</ref> Moosa was also a director of [http://www.horizonfisheries.com/ Horizon Fisheries Private Limited], a company with majority shares owned by Qasim Ibraim and former DRP member of parliament, Ahmed Nashid (ADK).
==Education== Moosa completed his secondary education at the [[Malé English School]], Malé. In 1990 he acquired General Certificate of Education with distinction in all subjects, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On 13 July 1995 he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with a B. Eng with honours in mechanical engineering. Two years later, in 1997, he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring PhD (Engineering) in metallurgy and materials.
==Political career== On 19 September 2003, [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life, the end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. The [[BBC]] covered this event and Moosa gave an interview to the BBC the following month and left Maldives, on 15 October 2003, to the [[United Kingdom]]. The interview was aired on 17 October 2003. He says he left the country because he believed he would be in danger if he remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said Sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on 10 November 2003, soon after its official announcement and was a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day-to-day operations of the party for two reasons. That is, MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview with the BBC, he gave several other interviews. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on 15 September 2006, Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on 11 April 2005. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in London. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act.<ref>[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/15/wmald15.xml ''The Telegraph'' "UK police warn wife of Maldives policeman over threat", 15 September 2006]</ref>
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/ Dhivehiobserver, a satirically political website by Moosa] **[http://www.facebook.com/asimoosa Facebook Page]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2011}}

He was appointed to his position on 11 March 2009 and resigned from the Maldivian government on 9 February 2012, soon after President Nasheed's government was allegedly overthrown by the incumbent President [[Mohammed Waheed Hassan]] two days earlier.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/maldives-aims-to-become-first-carbonneutral-country-1644907.html ''The Independent'' "Maldives aims to become first carbon-neutral country", 14 March 2009]</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/feb/07/mohamed-nasheed-resigns-maldives-president ''The Guarding'' "Mohamed Nasheed resigns as Maldives President", 7 February 2012]</ref> Moosa is amongst those who campaigned for democracy and [[human rights]] which led to the end of the 30 year rule of [[Gayoom]] in November 2008. He is the founder and [[editor-in-chief]] of the news website ''Dhivehi Observer''.<ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com ''Dhivehi Observer'']</ref><ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/aboutus.html ''Dhivehi Observer:About Us'']</ref>
Moosa is a senior member of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] and was elected to its first General Council. He was a widely outspoken critic of the former president [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]]. He lived in self-proclaimed [[exile]] in the [[United Kingdom]] with his family from 2003-2008. The opposition Coalition won the [[Maldivian presidential election, 2008|Presidential Election held in October 2008]].
Moosa resides in [[Glasgow]], United Kingdom as of 2009.<ref>[http://www.scotland.gov.uk/News/Releases/2009/12/1111143 ''Scotland-Maldives Partnership", 11 December 2009]</ref>
==Early and personal life== Moosa was born in [[Malé]], [[Maldives]]. He first married in 1995 and had three sons from that marriage: Adam, Michael and Daniel. He married secondly Fathimath Moosa, with whom he had a son and a daughter.
Before his political career began, Moosa filled several government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Pvt Ltd. The company was mainly involved in consultancy work in engineering, web design, printing and publishing, composition of business and marketing proposals and reports.
Moosa was practically involved in designing and production of the election campaign material for [[Ilyas Ibrahim]] (brother-in-law of the president Gayyoom) in 1999 who ran against [[Mohamed Nasheed]] (of the opposition) for representing the people of [[Malé]] as a member of the parliament. "I worked in Ilyas's last campaign (1999) on the request of Mr. Qasim Ibrahim which later turned out to be a regrettable experience." [http://www.minvanradio.com/do/maldives_statement_21Nov2004_dhivehiobserver.htm]
Since 1999 Moosa has been a consultant to [[Qasim Ibrahim]], Chairman of Villa Shipping and Trading Company, the largest private company in the Maldives. He is the leader of the [[Jumhooree Party]], which is part of the current government coalition.<ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa/CV%20of%20ASIMoosa.htm ''Dhivehi Observer'' Ahmed S. I. Moosa, Personal Details]</ref> Moosa was also a director of [http://www.horizonfisheries.com/ Horizon Fisheries Private Limited], a company with majority shares owned by Qasim Ibraim and former DRP member of parliament, Ahmed Nashid (ADK).
==Education== Moosa completed his secondary education at the [[Malé English School]], Malé. In 1990 he acquired General Certificate of Education with distinction in all subjects, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On 13 July 1995 he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with a B. Eng with honours in mechanical engineering. Two years later, in 1997, he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring PhD (Engineering) in metallurgy and materials.
==Political career== On 19 September 2003, [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi (Kaafu Atoll)|Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life, the end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. The [[BBC]] covered this event and Moosa gave an interview to the BBC the following month and left Maldives, on 15 October 2003, to the [[United Kingdom]]. The interview was aired on 17 October 2003. He says he left the country because he believed he would be in danger if he remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said Sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on 10 November 2003, soon after its official announcement and was a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day-to-day operations of the party for two reasons. That is, MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview with the BBC, he gave several other interviews. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on 15 September 2006, Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on 11 April 2005. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in London. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act.<ref>[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/15/wmald15.xml ''The Telegraph'' "UK police warn wife of Maldives policeman over threat", 15 September 2006]</ref>
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/ Dhivehiobserver, a satirically political website by Moosa] **[http://www.facebook.com/asimoosa Facebook Page]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2011}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2020}} {{Infobox officeholder | honorific-prefix = | name = Ahmed Moosa | native_name = | native_name_lang = | honorific-suffix = | image = Ahmed Moosa.jpg | image_size = | smallimage = <!--If this is specified, "image" should not be.--> | alt = | caption = | order = | office = Envoy for Science and Technology of the Maldives | term_start = 11 March 2009 | term_end = 9 February 2012 | president = [[Mohamed Nasheed]] | vice_president = [[Mohammed Waheed Hassan]] | predecessor = | successor = | birth_name = Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa | birth_place = [[Malé]], [[Maldives]] | nationality = Maldivian | party = [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] | spouse = | children = 5 | residence = [[Glasgow]], United Kingdom | education = [[University of Glasgow]] <small>(1995; BEng)</small> | occupation = [[Editor-in-chief]] }}
'''Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa''', also known as '''Sappé''', is a Maldivian editor-in-chief and politician who served as the first Envoy for Science and Technology to be appointed by the first democratically elected [[president of the Maldives]], [[Mohamed Nasheed]]. He was appointed to his position on 11 March 2009 and resigned from the Maldivian government on 9 February 2012, soon after President Nasheed's government was allegedly overthrown by the incumbent President [[Mohammed Waheed Hassan]] two days earlier.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/maldives-aims-to-become-first-carbonneutral-country-1644907.html ''The Independent'' "Maldives aims to become first carbon-neutral country", 14 March 2009]</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/feb/07/mohamed-nasheed-resigns-maldives-president ''The Guarding'' "Mohamed Nasheed resigns as Maldives President", 7 February 2012]</ref> Moosa is amongst those who campaigned for democracy and [[human rights]] which led to the end of the 30-year rule of [[Gayoom]] in November 2008. He is the founder and [[editor-in-chief]] of the news website ''Dhivehi Observer''.<ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com ''Dhivehi Observer'']</ref><ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/aboutus.html ''Dhivehi Observer:About Us''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110514045711/http://dhivehiobserver.com/aboutus.html |date=14 May 2011 }}</ref>
Moosa is a senior member of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] and was elected to its first General Council. He was a widely outspoken critic of the former president [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]]. He lived in self-proclaimed [[exile]] in the [[United Kingdom]] with his family from 2003–2008. The opposition Coalition won the [[2008 Maldivian presidential election|Presidential Election held in October 2008]].
Moosa resides in [[Glasgow]], United Kingdom as of 2009.<ref>[http://www.scotland.gov.uk/News/Releases/2009/12/1111143 ''Scotland-Maldives Partnership", 11 December 2009]</ref>
==Early and personal life== Moosa was born in [[Malé]], [[Maldives]]. He first married in 1995 and had three sons from that marriage: Adam, Michael and Daniel. He married secondly Fathimath Moosa, with whom he had a son and a daughter.
Before his political career began, Moosa filled several government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Pvt Ltd. The company was mainly involved in consultancy work in engineering, web design, printing and publishing, composition of business and marketing proposals and reports.
Moosa was practically involved in designing and production of the election campaign material for [[Ilyas Ibrahim]] (brother-in-law of the president Gayyoom) in 1999 who ran against [[Mohamed Nasheed]] (of the opposition) for representing the people of [[Malé]] as a member of the parliament. "I worked in Ilyas's last campaign (1999) on the request of Mr. Qasim Ibrahim which later turned out to be a regrettable experience." [http://www.minvanradio.com/do/maldives_statement_21Nov2004_dhivehiobserver.htm]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}
Since 1999 Moosa has been a consultant to [[Qasim Ibrahim]], Chairman of Villa Shipping and Trading Company, the largest private company in the Maldives. He is the leader of the [[Jumhooree Party]], which is part of the current government coalition.<ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa/CV%20of%20ASIMoosa.htm ''Dhivehi Observer'' Ahmed S. I. Moosa, Personal Details] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070410175944/http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa/CV%20of%20ASIMoosa.htm |date=10 April 2007 }}</ref> Moosa was also a director of [http://www.horizonfisheries.com/ Horizon Fisheries Private Limited], a company with majority shares owned by Qasim Ibraim and former DRP member of parliament, Ahmed Nashid (ADK).
==Education== Moosa completed his secondary education at the [[Malé English School]], Malé. In 1990 he acquired General Certificate of Education with distinction in all subjects, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On 13 July 1995 he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with a BEng with honours in mechanical engineering. Two years later, in 1997, he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring PhD (Engineering) in metallurgy and materials.
==Political career== On 19 September 2003, [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi (Kaafu Atoll)|Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life, the end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. The [[BBC]] covered this event and Moosa gave an interview to the BBC the following month and left Maldives, on 15 October 2003, to the [[United Kingdom]]. The interview was aired on 17 October 2003. He says he left the country because he believed he would be in danger if he remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said Sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on 10 November 2003, soon after its official announcement and was a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day-to-day operations of the party for two reasons. That is, MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview with the BBC, he gave several other interviews. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on 15 September 2006, Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on 11 April 2005. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in London. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/15/wmald15.xml ''The Telegraph'' "UK police warn wife of Maldives policeman over threat", 15 September 2006]</ref>
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/ Dhivehiobserver, a satirically political website by Moosa] **[http://www.facebook.com/asimoosa Facebook Page]
==References== {{Reflist}}
