Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in London. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=%2Fnews%2F2006%2F09%2F15%2Fwmald15.xml |title=''The Telegraph'' "UK police warn wife of Maldives policeman over threat", 15 September 2006 |access-date=12 March 2007 |archive-date=12 March 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070312213458/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=%2Fnews%2F2006%2F09%2F15%2Fwmald15.xml |url-status=dead }}</ref>
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/ Dhivehiobserver, a satirically political website by Moosa] **[http://www.facebook.com/asimoosa Facebook Page]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2020}} {{Infobox officeholder | honorific-prefix = | name = Ahmed Moosa | native_name = | native_name_lang = | honorific-suffix = | image = Ahmed Moosa.jpg | image_size = | smallimage = <!--If this is specified, "image" should not be.--> | alt = | caption = | order = | office = Envoy for Science and Technology of the Maldives | term_start = 11 March 2009 | term_end = 9 February 2012 | president = [[Mohamed Nasheed]] | vice_president = [[Mohammed Waheed Hassan]] | predecessor = | successor = | birth_name = Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa | birth_place = [[Malé]], [[Maldives]] | nationality = Maldivian | party = [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] | spouse = | children = 6 | residence = [[Glasgow]], United Kingdom | education = [[University of Glasgow]] <small>(1995; BEng)</small> | occupation = [[Editor-in-chief]] }}
'''Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa''', also known as '''Sappé''', is a Maldivian editor-in-chief and politician who served as the first Envoy for Science and Technology to be appointed by the first democratically elected [[president of the Maldives]], [[Mohamed Nasheed]]. He was appointed to his position on 11 March 2009 and resigned from the Maldivian government on 9 February 2012, soon after President Nasheed's government was allegedly overthrown by the incumbent President [[Mohammed Waheed Hassan]] two days earlier.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/maldives-aims-to-become-first-carbonneutral-country-1644907.html ''The Independent'' "Maldives aims to become first carbon-neutral country", 14 March 2009]</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/feb/07/mohamed-nasheed-resigns-maldives-president ''The Guarding'' "Mohamed Nasheed resigns as Maldives President", 7 February 2012]</ref> Moosa is amongst those who campaigned for democracy and [[human rights]] which led to the end of the 30-year rule of [[Gayoom]] in November 2008. He is the founder and [[editor-in-chief]] of the news website ''Dhivehi Observer''.<ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com ''Dhivehi Observer'']</ref><ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/aboutus.html ''Dhivehi Observer:About Us''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110514045711/http://dhivehiobserver.com/aboutus.html |date=14 May 2011 }}</ref>
Moosa is a senior member of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] and was elected to its first General Council. He was a widely outspoken critic of the former president [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]]. He lived in self-proclaimed [[exile]] in the [[United Kingdom]] with his family from 2003–2008. The opposition Coalition won the [[2008 Maldivian presidential election|Presidential Election held in October 2008]].
Moosa resides in [[Glasgow]], United Kingdom as of 2009.<ref>[http://www.scotland.gov.uk/News/Releases/2009/12/1111143 ''Scotland-Maldives Partnership", 11 December 2009]</ref>
==Early and personal life== Moosa was born in [[Malé]], [[Maldives]]. He first married in 1995 and had three sons from that marriage: Adam, Michael and Daniel. He married secondly Fathimath Moosa, with whom he had a son and a daughter.
Before his political career began, Moosa filled several government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Pvt Ltd. The company was mainly involved in consultancy work in engineering, web design, printing and publishing, composition of business and marketing proposals and reports.
Moosa was practically involved in designing and production of the election campaign material for [[Ilyas Ibrahim]] (brother-in-law of the president Gayyoom) in 1999 who ran against [[Mohamed Nasheed]] (of the opposition) for representing the people of [[Malé]] as a member of the parliament. "I worked in Ilyas's last campaign (1999) on the request of Mr. Qasim Ibrahim which later turned out to be a regrettable experience." [http://www.minvanradio.com/do/maldives_statement_21Nov2004_dhivehiobserver.htm]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}
Since 1999 Moosa has been a consultant to [[Qasim Ibrahim]], Chairman of Villa Shipping and Trading Company, the largest private company in the Maldives. He is the leader of the [[Jumhooree Party]], which is part of the current government coalition.<ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa/CV%20of%20ASIMoosa.htm ''Dhivehi Observer'' Ahmed S. I. Moosa, Personal Details] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070410175944/http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa/CV%20of%20ASIMoosa.htm |date=10 April 2007 }}</ref>
==Education== Moosa completed his secondary education at the [[Malé English School]], Malé. In 1990 he acquired General Certificate of Education with distinction in all subjects, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On 13 July 1995 he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with a BEng with honours in mechanical engineering. Two years later, in 1997, he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring PhD (Engineering) in metallurgy and materials.
==Political career== On 19 September 2003, [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi (Kaafu Atoll)|Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life, the end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. The [[BBC]] covered this event and Moosa gave an interview to the BBC the following month and left Maldives, on 15 October 2003, to the [[United Kingdom]]. The interview was aired on 17 October 2003. He says he left the country because he believed he would be in danger if he remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said Sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on 10 November 2003, soon after its official announcement and was a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day-to-day operations of the party for two reasons. That is, MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview with the BBC, he gave several other interviews. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on 15 September 2006, Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on 11 April 2005. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in London. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=%2Fnews%2F2006%2F09%2F15%2Fwmald15.xml |title=''The Telegraph'' "UK police warn wife of Maldives policeman over threat", 15 September 2006 |access-date=12 March 2007 |archive-date=12 March 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070312213458/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=%2Fnews%2F2006%2F09%2F15%2Fwmald15.xml |url-status=dead }}</ref>
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/ Dhivehiobserver, a satirically political website by Moosa] **[http://www.facebook.com/asimoosa Facebook Page]
==References== {{Reflist}}

He is the leader of the [[Jumhooree Party]], which is part of the current government coalition.<ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa/CV%20of%20ASIMoosa.htm ''Dhivehi Observer'' Ahmed S. I. Moosa, Personal Details] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070410175944/http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa/CV%20of%20ASIMoosa.htm |date=10 April 2007 }}</ref>
==Education== Moosa completed his secondary education at the [[Malé English School]], Malé. In 1990 he acquired General Certificate of Education with distinction in all subjects, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On 13 July 1995 he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with a BEng with honours in mechanical engineering. Two years later, in 1997, he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring PhD (Engineering) in metallurgy and materials.
==Political career== On 19 September 2003, [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi (Kaafu Atoll)|Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life, the end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. The [[BBC]] covered this event and Moosa gave an interview to the BBC the following month and left Maldives, on 15 October 2003, to the [[United Kingdom]]. The interview was aired on 17 October 2003. He says he left the country because he believed he would be in danger if he remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said Sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on 10 November 2003, soon after its official announcement and was a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day-to-day operations of the party for two reasons. That is, MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview with the BBC, he gave several other interviews. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on 15 September 2006, Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on 11 April 2005. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in London. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=%2Fnews%2F2006%2F09%2F15%2Fwmald15.xml |title=''The Telegraph'' "UK police warn wife of Maldives policeman over threat", 15 September 2006 |access-date=12 March 2007 |archive-date=12 March 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070312213458/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=%2Fnews%2F2006%2F09%2F15%2Fwmald15.xml |url-status=dead }}</ref>
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/ Dhivehiobserver, a satirically political website by Moosa] **[http://www.facebook.com/asimoosa Facebook Page]
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2020}} {{Infobox officeholder | honorific-prefix = | name = Ahmed Moosa | native_name = | native_name_lang = | honorific-suffix = | image = Ahmed Moosa.jpg | image_size = | smallimage = <!--If this is specified, "image" should not be.--> | alt = | caption = | order = | office = Envoy for Science and Technology of the Maldives | term_start = 11 March 2009 | term_end = 9 February 2012 | president = [[Mohamed Nasheed]] | vice_president = [[Mohammed Waheed Hassan]] | predecessor = | successor = | birth_name = Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa | birth_place = [[Malé]], [[Maldives]] | nationality = Maldivian | party = [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] | spouse = | children = 6 | residence = [[Glasgow]], United Kingdom | education = [[University of Glasgow]] <small>(1995; BEng)</small> | occupation = [[Editor-in-chief]] }}
'''Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa''' ([[Maldivian language|Dhivehi]]: އަހްމަދު ޝަފީގް އިބްރާހިމް މޫސާ) ('''b.''' [[November 4]], [[1968]]), also known as '''Sappé''', is a Maldivian editor-in-chief and politician who served as the first Envoy for Science and Technology to be appointed by the first democratically elected [[president of the Maldives]], [[Mohamed Nasheed]]. He was appointed to his position on 11 March 2009 and resigned from the Maldivian government on 9 February 2012, soon after President Nasheed's government was allegedly overthrown by the incumbent President [[Mohammed Waheed Hassan]] two days earlier.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/maldives-aims-to-become-first-carbonneutral-country-1644907.html ''The Independent'' "Maldives aims to become first carbon-neutral country", 14 March 2009]</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/feb/07/mohamed-nasheed-resigns-maldives-president ''The Guarding'' "Mohamed Nasheed resigns as Maldives President", 7 February 2012]</ref> Moosa is amongst those who campaigned for democracy and [[human rights]] which led to the end of the 30-year rule of [[Gayoom]] in November 2008. He is the founder and [[editor-in-chief]] of the news website ''Dhivehi Observer''.<ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com ''Dhivehi Observer'']</ref><ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/aboutus.html ''Dhivehi Observer:About Us''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110514045711/http://dhivehiobserver.com/aboutus.html |date=14 May 2011 }}</ref>
Moosa is a senior member of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] and was elected to its first General Council. He was a widely outspoken critic of the former president [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]]. He lived in self-proclaimed [[exile]] in the [[United Kingdom]] with his family from 2003–2008. The opposition Coalition won the [[2008 Maldivian presidential election|Presidential Election held in October 2008]].
Moosa resides in [[Glasgow]], United Kingdom as of 2009.<ref>[http://www.scotland.gov.uk/News/Releases/2009/12/1111143 ''Scotland-Maldives Partnership'', 11 December 2009]</ref>
==Early and personal life== Moosa was born in [[Malé]], [[Maldives]]. He first married in 1995 and had three sons from that marriage: Adam, Michael and Daniel. He married secondly Fathimath Moosa, with whom he had a son and a daughter, Alexander and Enya. He later married Aminath Moosa and had a daughter, Emma.
Before his political career began, Moosa filled several government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Pvt Ltd. The company was mainly involved in consultancy work in engineering, web design, printing and publishing, composition of business and marketing proposals and reports.
Moosa was practically involved in designing and production of the election campaign material for [[Ilyas Ibrahim]] (brother-in-law of the president Gayyoom) in 1999 who ran against [[Mohamed Nasheed]] (of the opposition) for representing the people of [[Malé]] as a member of the parliament. "I worked in Ilyas's last campaign (1999) on the request of Mr. Qasim Ibrahim which later turned out to be a regrettable experience." [http://www.minvanradio.com/do/maldives_statement_21Nov2004_dhivehiobserver.htm]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}
Since 1999 Moosa has been a consultant to [[Qasim Ibrahim]], Chairman of Villa Shipping and Trading Company, the largest private company in the Maldives. He is the leader of the [[Jumhooree Party]], which is part of the current government coalition.<ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa/CV%20of%20ASIMoosa.htm ''Dhivehi Observer'' Ahmed S. I. Moosa, Personal Details] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070410175944/http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa/CV%20of%20ASIMoosa.htm |date=10 April 2007 }}</ref>
==Education== Moosa completed his secondary education at the [[Malé English School]], Malé. In 1990 he acquired General Certificate of Education with distinction in all subjects, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On 13 July 1995 he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with a BEng with honours in mechanical engineering. Two years later, in 1997, he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring PhD (Engineering) in metallurgy and materials.
==Political career== On 19 September 2003, [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi (Kaafu Atoll)|Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life, the end result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. The [[BBC]] covered this event and Moosa gave an interview to the BBC the following month and left Maldives, on 15 October 2003, to the [[United Kingdom]]. The interview was aired on 17 October 2003. He says he left the country because he believed he would be in danger if he remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said Sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on 10 November 2003, soon after its official announcement and was a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day-to-day operations of the party for two reasons. That is, MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview with the BBC, he gave several other interviews. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on 15 September 2006, Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on 11 April 2005. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in London. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=%2Fnews%2F2006%2F09%2F15%2Fwmald15.xml |title=''The Telegraph'' "UK police warn wife of Maldives policeman over threat", 15 September 2006 |access-date=12 March 2007 |archive-date=12 March 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070312213458/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=%2Fnews%2F2006%2F09%2F15%2Fwmald15.xml |url-status=dead }}</ref>
==External links== *[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/ Dhivehiobserver, a satirically political website by Moosa] **[http://www.facebook.com/asimoosa Facebook Page]

'''Ahmed Shafeeq Ibrahim Moosa''' ([[Maldivian language|Dhivehi]]: އަހްމަދު ޝަފީގް އިބްރާހިމް މޫސާ) ('''b.''' [[November 4]], [[1968]]), also known as '''Sappé''', is a Maldivian editor-in-chief and politician who served as the first Envoy for Science and Technology to be appointed by the first democratically elected [[president of the Maldives]], [[Mohamed Nasheed]]. He was appointed to his position on 11 March 2009 and resigned from the Maldivian government on 9 February 2012, soon after President Nasheed's government was allegedly overthrown by the incumbent President [[Mohammed Waheed Hassan]] two days earlier.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Taylor |first=Jerome |last2=Buncombe |first2=Andrew |date=14 March 2009 |title=Maldives aims to become first carbon-neutral country |work=The Independent |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/maldives-aims-to-become-first-carbonneutral-country-1644907.html}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Burke |first=Jason |date=2012-02-07 |title=Mohamed Nasheed resigns as Maldives president |language=en-GB |work=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/feb/07/mohamed-nasheed-resigns-maldives-president |access-date=2023-12-24 |issn=0261-3077}}</ref> Moosa is amongst those who campaigned for democracy and [[human rights]] which led to the end of the 30-year rule of [[Gayoom]] in November 2008. He is the founder and [[editor-in-chief]] of the news website ''Dhivehi Observer''.<ref>{{Cite web |title=About Us - Dhivehi Observer: Peoples Press |url=http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/aboutus.html |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110514045711/http://dhivehiobserver.com/aboutus.html |archive-date=14 May 2011}}</ref>
Moosa is a senior member of the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] and was elected to its first General Council. He was a widely outspoken critic of the former president [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]]. He lived in self-proclaimed [[exile]] in the [[United Kingdom]] with his family from 2003 to 2008. The opposition Coalition won the [[2008 Maldivian presidential election|Presidential Election held in October 2008]].
Moosa resides in [[Glasgow]], [[United Kingdom]] as of 2009.<ref>[http://www.scotland.gov.uk/News/Releases/2009/12/1111143 ''Scotland-Maldives Partnership'', 11 December 2009]</ref>
==Early and personal life== Moosa was born in [[Malé]], [[Maldives]]. He first married in 1995 and had three sons from that marriage: Adam, Michael and Daniel. He married secondly Fathimath Moosa, with whom he had a son and a daughter, Alexander and Enya. He later married Aminath Moosa and had a daughter, Emma.
Before his political career began, Moosa filled several government and private company posts. He also managed and ran his own businesses. In March 1999 he founded ''A'' Company Pvt Ltd. The company was mainly involved in consultancy work in engineering, web design, printing and publishing, composition of business and marketing proposals and reports.
Moosa was practically involved in designing and production of the election campaign material for [[Ilyas Ibrahim]] (brother-in-law of the president Gayoom) in 1999 who ran against [[Mohamed Nasheed]] (of the opposition) for representing the people of [[Malé]] as a member of the parliament. "I worked in Ilyas's last campaign (1999) on the request of Mr. Qasim Ibrahim which later turned out to be a regrettable experience." [http://www.minvanradio.com/do/maldives_statement_21Nov2004_dhivehiobserver.htm]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}
Since 1999 Moosa has been a consultant to [[Qasim Ibrahim]], Chairman of [[Villa Group|Villa Shipping and Trading Company]], the largest private company in the Maldives. He is the leader of the [[Jumhooree Party]], which is part of the current government coalition.<ref>[http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa/CV%20of%20ASIMoosa.htm ''Dhivehi Observer'' Ahmed S. I. Moosa, Personal Details] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070410175944/http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/moosa/CV%20of%20ASIMoosa.htm |date=10 April 2007 }}</ref>
==Education== Moosa completed his secondary education at the [[Malé English School]], Malé. In 1990 he acquired General Certificate of Education with distinction in all subjects, from [[Asmai Secondary School]], [[Kuwait]]. On 13 July 1995 he graduated from [[University of Glasgow]] with a BEng with honours in mechanical engineering. Two years later, in 1997, he graduated at [[University of Birmingham]] acquiring PhD (Engineering) in metallurgy and materials.
==Political career== On 19 September 2003, [[Evan Naseem]] who was serving at [[Maafushi (Kaafu Atoll)|Maafushi]] jail was severely beaten up and ultimately paid with his life, the result of a series of complicated disputes between inmates. News broke out the following day and there was a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|civil unrest in the capital city]] of the [[Maldives]], [[Malé]]. The [[BBC]] covered this event and Moosa gave an interview to the BBC the following month and left Maldives, on 15 October 2003, to the [[United Kingdom]]. The interview was aired on 17 October 2003. He says he left the country because he believed he would be in danger if he remained in Maldives. "I have already left the country fearing the worst" said Sappé in a written statement published on his website.
He joined the [[Maldivian Democratic Party]] on 10 November 2003, soon after its official announcement and was a member of its general council. However, he does not get involved with day-to-day operations of the party for two reasons. That is, MDP's major operations are carried out in [[Sri Lanka]] and he operates his own website DhivehiObserver, which is his major line of connection with the Maldivian public.
After his initial interview with the BBC, he gave several other interviews. They appeared to have exerted pressure on Maldivian government.
According to the article published on [[The Daily Telegraph]] on 15 September 2006, Ahmed Moosa was threatened via email by the wife of police commissioner [[Adam Zahir]], Husna Latheef, on 11 April 2005. Moosa filed a complaint to [[Wiltshire Police]] who investigated the death threat with the assistance of the [[Metropolitan Police]] in London. The threat was traced back to Husna Latheef's email and was issued with a first verbal warning under the Harassment Act.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Foster |first=Peter |date=15 September 2009 |title=UK police warn wife of Maldives policeman over threat |work=Telegraph |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=%2Fnews%2F2006%2F09%2F15%2Fwmald15.xml |url-status=dead |access-date=12 March 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070312213458/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=%2Fnews%2F2006%2F09%2F15%2Fwmald15.xml |archive-date=12 March 2007}}</ref>
